reviews.review_title: Uniquely normal and different
reviews.content: I saw a good movie. It was different...."ME and EARL and the DYING GIRL"This movie was not released in India. It is not a normal "normal" movie. The way it is scripted is slightly different. It is based on a debut novel of Jesse Andrews with the same name.Greg (Thomas Mann) is a loner in high school. He is forced by his parents to meet a childhood friend Rachel (Olivia Cooke) who has been diagnosed with cancer. At first neither of two are interested in each other, but Greg's quirkiness interests Rachel and they meet regularly. Grey introduces her to his friend Earl (RJ Cyler) with whom he is making parodies of famous films. Earl convinces Greg to spend more time with Rachel. Grey , unknowingly sacrifices his life, his studies, his work, because he wants to make a film for Rachel. When Rachel's opts out of chemotherapy, Greg is devastated and argues with her and fights with Earl.who thinks Greg is very insensitive person. When Rachel - in the final stage of cancer and admitted to hospital -depresses Grey more. In the end Greg visits Rachel to show the film he made for her. While watching the film Rachel falls in a coma and dies after few hours. Greg reads a letter written by Rachel. He realizes that like him Rachel too was in LOVE. Greg pens down a book about his LOVE and along with the video mails it to his college.The film reflects a deeper complexities of feelings among two people in LOVE - who meet each other, exchange and talk to each other - but face an ordeal to cognizant & accept their LOVE feeling...Director Alfanso who was an assistant to Martin Scorsese wanted to show his style of film-making sensibilities reflecting the loss he faced in life of his father through this filmHe does a commendable job directing this unique interesting film. Thomas Mann and Olivia Cooke have acted well along with Rj Cyler, whose role as Earl is a bit curtailed in the movie. The movie grabbed several awards and nominations in many festivals. The songs of the movie are heart-warming. It is a good watch for people who are not in touch with their own sense of inner LOVE and unaware of their feelings of LOVE for others.I would go with 6.25

reviews.review_title: Overall Well-Done, but Very Predictable Too
reviews.content: I was pretty interested in seeing this movie. The title is quite catchy, and the ratings were quite good. After watching it I must say that those ratings are well-deserved for the most part. Me and Earl and the Dying Girl has a somewhat different and kind of funny plot. A boy is told he has to hang out with a girl who has cancer, but he doesn't want to do it and ends up becoming friends with her anyways. It's one of those 'unlikely friendship' stories, but it's done pretty well for the most part. It's overall a pretty funny movie too, so the somewhat goofy plot fits really well. Unfortunately this movie follows a formula that we all know and love. The only difference is that this one follows the average romantic movie formula but it's not a romance. I found that I was really hoping that certain things didn't happen, but then they did anyways, over and over until eventually it became apparent that this was the formula. A movie being formulaic isn't always a bad thing, but in this movie it just stood out as something poorly done while everything else is well done for the most part. The characters are pretty good. They're obviously the focus of the movie, but I felt like they could have been developed a little better. Greg's character felt a little out of place, being the 'lonely kid-that-everyone-likes-but-still-has-no-friends-but-is- actually-really-fun-to-be-around', which is a character that I think we've all seen before. Although his character is done well for the most part, he's still not fantastic. Earl felt like he had a pretty minor part in the movie, and we never go too deep into his character, nor does he get nearly enough screen time. Then there's Rachel, the dying girl, whom I thought was the best of the characters. She felt the most like a real person of all of them. However, I feel like the relationship between Rachel and Greg could have been done better, instead of being shown through a montage of them hanging out more towards the end. It was still done well, but I think that it could have been better. I found that the characters didn't stand out that much either, other then Greg's parents, whom I liked quite a bit. Overall Me and Earl and the Dying Girl is pretty good, but suffers from predictability and not-the-greatest characters. There were a few very small things about the movie that also really bothered me, but they aren't overly important. In the end, though, I'd still definitely recommend this movie. It's still lot's of fun to watch.

reviews.review_title: Odd Priorities
reviews.content: Me and Earl and the Dying Girl focuses on a cynical, self-hating teenager, Greg. He narrates his senior year by explaining how less special he is and how terrible high school is. He believes that his self-awareness about his shortcomings would make him sound smarter, but it also makes him sound even more selfish. Until, of course, he befriends with this girl who was just diagnosed with leukemia and suppose to earn sympathy towards her and realize that there are people dealing with bigger problems than his own. The movie thankfully doesn't hammer in some full sentimentality and it's wise enough to keeping itself honest towards the issues they are dealing with. But even so, the film feels a little too shallow, while the craft is admirable, it seems like much of the effort came to that work of pretension rather than rising this story into something much more compelling. Nonetheless, it's still quite entertaining, but it still deserves something a lot better.The movie's only concern is how Greg would grow to this part of his high school life, how interacting with Rachel would somehow change him to finally empathize other people. The film avoids the simple sappiness that often resolves their issues, like the hero would instantly get a change of heart, life instantly gets better and only destroyed by death or something. The film rather find more subtle ways to develop the character, reminding us that his cynicism shouldn't be taken away that easily. But it would have been more interesting if it explores the other characters and their concern; Earl seems like a typical best friend, or they shall call it co-worker, no matter how much they explain how different he is for his history. His backstory is briefly explained and that wouldn't be enough if he is suppose to be as important as the other two main characters. Much important is Rachel, who clearly easily wants to give up after losing her hair and everything, but she seems to be just an element for Greg to sympathize and have friends with. It's nice that their concern was more about what will happen to the lives of her loved ones when she's gone, rather than crying over a dream that will never be fulfilled. But this Rachel needs more personal outlook than just something to help out Greg. Even as Greg's point of view, it should be more thoughtful than what is is presented.And again, much of the priority went to the style. And that's no problem at all. It makes it often visually interesting; from creative shots and sketchy imagery, it's fine to get a dose of symmetry and random stop motion. It might as well be a tribute to classic cinema since the characters have been lampooning each one of them creatively with their home sized budget. But this side isn't quite the meat of the story. I won't shame the effort and the enthusiasm of bringing a quirky personality around this atmosphere, but the story is still demanding something that should have been taken more seriously.The acting is nice; Thomas Mann manages to bring likability to a character that is tough to empathize. Olivia Cooke has proved that she has potential, but this role sadly isn't the one that would fully showcase that talent, though to be fair, this role isn't given any deeper exploration that it deserves. Same with RJ Cyler who as well could have made their bond more interesting, but there isn't much of him here either. The supporting cast such as Nick Offerman, Connie Britton, Molly Shannon, Jon Bernthal are top notch. Most of them get unexpected and even somewhat remarkable turns in their smaller roles.The best parts of Me and Earl and the Dying Girl is when it stops being pretentious and starts focusing at the bigger picture. But so little time spent in those moments kept the experience from being rewarding. I mean the craft is still admirable and it makes it more fun to explore this high school life in a different spin compared to many overly done coming-of-age cynicism film out there. But this movie handling a story that deserves attention towards its themes than its style and flavor. Style and flavor is good, but as long as it doesn't take away what should have been the heart of the story. With that said, it's still more realistic in the sense of a normal teenager than many modern mainstream coming-of-age movies out there. It's still entertaining to watch and there is still some heartfelt moments that are worth the shot. It's just it could have been more profound than this.

reviews.review_title: Realistic, sometimes poignant, and mostly-fun film
reviews.content: 'Me and Earl and the Dying Girl' is a solid coming-of-age film - it's charming and funny and definitely not as depressing as the title may have you believe. It's a simple concept - the not-quite nerdy, not-quite cool high-schooler, Greg (Mann), is forced by his mum to hang out with a classmate who has just being diagnosed with leukaemia, Rachel (Cooke). It's starts off as an awkward friendship, but slowly turns into genuine friendship.Earl (Cyler) is great as Greg's only friend (or "co-worker" as he calls him) and lots of the film's fun comes from the parodies they make together of classic films - such as 'Senior Citizen Cane', 'The Seven Seals', 'A Sockwork Orange', 'Eyes Wide Butt' & my favourite, 'Grumpy Cul-de-Sacs'! - most featuring clever animation and hilarious ultra-low-budget imitations. Earl acts as Greg's conscience when he turns into a shellfish teenager and forgets about Rachel's actual problems. The parents (Shannon, Offerman & Britton) all have some great scenes.The film's score, by Brian Eno, is fantastic and really adds to the emotion, especially towards the end. The finale is handled well and shows impact we can have others' lives by just being there for them. Sure, it's sad in parts, but it's realistic and it is nice to watch how Greg and Rachel handle the situation mostly with good-humour. The funny moments outweigh the sad ones and make this an enjoyable film.

Well, I am not saying this grumpily, yet here's another film from 2015 which I was really looking forward to and ended up not living to its potential nor to its promise back when I heard of it in very late 2014.I really, really like the basic ground of this film. I really appreciate the ideas it is putting forwards, the context and the intentions, even though some of them are frustratingly unoriginal, but still well intended. What I don't like here is characters and execution. I think this film fails in style, tone and more importantly character empathy.It is too full of itself and it is unbearably quirky for its own good. The point is: I am not against quirky at all, look at something like "Paper Towns", one of my favorite movies of the year, that has loads of it in, but it works and I like it because it fits the characters it is portraying, it comes from an interesting place and becomes an integrating part of the story.In this movie is used arrogantly and it becomes a turn off on the characters. From the very start I simply kept realizing to myself I was not getting on board with this. I kept being emotionally stale and distant to all of the characters of this film and it never does some pick up so all the character beats of this film missed it for me. It was a mix that didn't work in my opinion, these characters and this tone, as I said before, it didn't match, but I believe that is not because of my personal taste, it's because truly this story doesn't lend itself to this type of telling, the characters looked out of place.That's possibly the only negative I have for the film, but it's a pretty big one when you consider that for the most part I saw simply emotionally absent from the film and didn't care about it much at all.Now of course I did get a couple of feels from it at moments, but that is both because of the subject matter, but even more so because of how well it is crafted. I have to give props to the director for the use of these long takes that I couldn't get enough of, unfortunately the world they captured and the way in which the characters moved and talked it in was really different from how the camera move. I must admit that out of personal curiosity I would really like to see a version of this film with some more editing in it, more cuts, just a more frenetic pace to the scenes. I believe that it would really lend itself tonally to how the story was being told, more.Nevertheless, I really appreciated all of the ground work the film had going for it, it was compelling to watch, but the execution really didn't pay off repeatedly and sadly so.

reviews.review_title: A comical allegory
reviews.content: I have been meaning to write the review of Me and Earl and the Dying Girl for so long that it makes me sad to see it stand waiting for so long, in the backcloth of my mind, hungry for appreciation. It deserves adulation. It deserves your attention. My sole intent is to shower undying love for this intensely deep and touching movie that beats every convention that mainstream cinema sells us today.DIRECTION OF ME AND EARL AND THE DYING GIRL Me and Earl and the Dying Girl is a constant droll that stays beautifully supplemented by the subtle direction of Alfonso Gomez-Rejon. What you cannot certainly overlook is its extraordinary cinematography that pays attention to meticulous details at different crises. If you pay attention enough you will approve the existence of the genius behind the camera.Alfonso's frames are in a perfect sync with the flick's deadpan. Also, you are invariably smiling at the way things are shown which makes Me and Earl and the Dying Girl a propitious watch. Camera's superlative swiveling from a single axle point and such countless experimentation throughout, will make you realize how Jesse Andrews might not have been able to get a better director for this movie.Apart from stunning camera movements, the flick scores high on editing too. It stays fueled by its perfect timing for skipping frames, or throwing in a funny jest every now and then. Best ones are stop motion animation scenes that try to expound what our protagonist is thinking. It is intelligently depicted, and bides by its "out of the box" thinking.PLOT OF THE DYING GIRL (SPOILERS) Even though the titular flick gives away the primal plot through the moniker itself, it balances on a mere assertion to show us what might or might not happen. Me and Earl and the Dying Girl stays in the head of Greg played by Thomas Mann at all times, and depicts coming of age stuff from his perspective. We also have Earl who is Greg's best friend, played by RJ Cyler who gives a brilliant icing to the story. There are subplots to the tale that unveil as a result of an unusual setup which get superbly helmed too.It also has 21 mini movies that tell you how talented and amazing the brains behind the Me and Earl and the Dying Girl are. All of these short movies land up one way or the other inside the flick, and you can't help but reflect on your childhood dreams. You are compelled to brood over that passion of yours that could never really go anywhere.Olivia Cooke as Rachel is absolutely perfect for the role. Her eyes do most of the talking, and you can't thank the casting director enough to have chosen her. Earl doesn't disappoint either. He creates this perfect comportment to depict 'distance' whenever it was the call of the hour. Thomas Mann can't be applauded enough. His Greg brings plausibility to the tale and makes him a very promising character.FILM FOR RACHEL The final movie on Rachel is a colossal metaphor. It leaves you wondering about things that constantly float in the head of Greg. It is hard to picture someone as furled as Greg have gargantuan profundity hidden.There are images that run wild without words that try to say bazillion things to Rachel. It is Brian Eno's music, and Greg's animation that speak up abstract thoughts in a language only Rachel understands. It is so beautiful and poetic at the same time that you cannot clap enough for the writer to have thought something as eccentric as that.THE FINAL VERDICT Me and Earl and the Dying Girl is a fun frolic into the lives of Greg, Earl and Rachel. But the tragedy that awaits or doesn't, at the culmination point is going to leave your mind impassioned with emotions. A must watch!

There's not many films that I have watched and not been swayed on the rating, but this is an exception. There is no one that can persuade me against thinking this is a great film, an original film, a moving fillm. It;s honestly genuinely funny, and so relatable. Just watch it honestly.

At first the two of them don't really want to be around each but eventually over time the two of them develop a friendship and learn through each other, I will say while the film is heartbreaking but it also has moments of laughter and showing the path of self discovery as Greg realizes he matters and can make a difference.

reviews.review_title: Profound perfection
reviews.content: Last year, I was amazed by the wonderfully emotional and powerful teen drama: The Fault In Our Stars. This film revolves around a similar premise with 'The Dying Girl', however it really goes to infinity and beyond to create one of the most incredible movie experiences I've ever seen. Stylistically and emotionally, this is a film that will amaze you in so many ways.Let's start with the main impact of this film, and that's the beautifully touching and heartbreaking story of the relationship between Rachel, a girl diagnosed with leukaemia, and Greg, a boy who reluctantly becomes good friends with her.With incredible performances by both actors, this is one of the most genuine and convincing on-screen friendships you've ever seen, and that's so significant when it comes to packing the emotional punch of the inevitable latter stages of the story, where things take a more dramatic, but still unpredictable turn.One of the most excellent parts of this film is that it's also brilliantly self-aware. It knows that many found The Fault In Our Stars cheesy, and think that this genre isn't really what it says it is. However, this uses its often more light-hearted tone to react to that stigma, and really turn the tables to create a story that will wholly enthral you no matter what your preconceptions about the genre are.In terms of the comedic tone of this film, it's also fantastic. The first half of the story is pretty much a comedy, however it's just as intelligent and fascinating as the drama is. Again, being so self-aware, this film presents itself as a quirky indie story that many hate, and while sticking to some tropes of the genre, it again subverts all of the main stereotypes to once again make something truly genuine and original, and one that will definitely stun you.Finally, this is also such an amazing film from a stylistic point of view. Not only does it fill itself with an unbelievable and powerful score, but Gomez-Rejon's directing is so original and impressive. Whether it's using an odd side-angle shot, or putting the actors through some of the longest takes you've ever seen, this is an amazing film to witness as well as experience.

reviews.review_title: The Unsiprising Tear Jerker Of The Year
reviews.content: you know instantly when you go into this film that it's not going to be an all happy film, with just the themes alone, this deeply moving and at times sad film, really grabs you. It is a superb film, much similar to that of The Fault in Our Stars, which feels genuine and touching, without getting too sappy for its own good. Maybe it's just me, but the main character, Greg, was a spitting image of what I was like at school. On top of this, Earl is the friend that everyone has, so the entire film settles you in for a very personal assault on your emotions. Maybe at times this film feels slightly forced, but with that aside, Me and Earl and The Dying Girl is a true depiction of friendship and loss. I have a feeling you will not experience a film like this again this year.

I don't remember their names, or what they said, or did. The ending was particularly creepy -- the boy sneaking into the dead girl's room and looking at her things, and trying to find meaning in it. It was empty.

reviews.review_title: "Me and Earl and the Dying Girl" speaks with an authentic and sincere voice.
reviews.content: It's tough to be a teenager – and it's getting tougher. In the last few years, I've seen teenagers rebel against a society that forces them into a certain career path, some having to fight and even kill each other for food, still others run through a dangerous maze so they no longer have to live in the woods and then, there's cancer. As good as the "Divergent", "Hunger Games" and "Maze Runner" movies are, nothing tugs at the heartstrings like kids with cancer. "The Fault in Our Stars" dramatized that very effectively, while the latest YA novel to hit the big screen, "Me and Earl and the Dying Girl" (PG-13, 1:45), tackles the same subject from a more light-hearted, but no less heartfelt perspective.The "Me" in the title is intelligent and creative, but awkward Pittsburgh high school senior Greg Gaines (Thomas Mann), who is friends with a guy named Earl (Ronald Cyler II) and Rachel (Olivia Cooke), a girl with leukemia. But Greg would hesitate to use the word "friend" for either Earl or Rachel. Greg's strategy for surviving high school is to be breezily acquainted with kids in each of his school's cliques, but let no one really get to know him. (Greg has serious self-esteem issues.) Earl calls Greg his friend, while the well-meaning but aloof Greg calls Earl his "co-worker". The two have known each other since kindergarten and bonded over their shared hobby of making admittedly awful short film versions of old movies, after altering the titles, which alters the plots. ("A Clockwork Orange" becomes "A Sockwork Orange", "Midnight Cowboy" becomes "2:48 Cowboy", "Apocalypse Now" becomes "A Box Slips, Wow", etc.) Greg only becomes friends with Rachel because his parents (Connie Britton and Nick Offerman) force him into it after they learn of Rachel's diagnosis.Rachel isn't interested in a friendship based on pity, but she is amused by Greg's quirky personality which is on full display as he gives a friendship with Rachel the old college try. Speaking of college, something else his mom nags him about is getting around to applying to college. Rachel finally convinces him to do so, and he encourages her to do the same, stubbornly optimistic about her chances for recovery. College starts to seem less likely for both of them as Rachel fights through chemotherapy and Greg virtually abandons his school responsibilities in favor of being there for Rachel.One thing Greg does that brings a smile to Rachel's face is letting his guard down enough to allow her to see his and Earl's private collection of homemade celluloid schlock. Madison (Katherine C. Hughes), Greg's high school crush, encourages him and Earl to make a film for Rachel and they agree. But this is no longer just two teenagers traipsing through the woods with a movie camera for their own amusement. This is deadly serious and none of their ideas and efforts seems appropriate or even good. Earl, Madison and a very cool history teacher (Jon Bernthal) all encourage Greg to look beyond his self-centeredness and focus on Rachel, but he's emotionally ill-equipped to deal with her declining health. The stress takes its toll, driving a wedge between him and Earl – and between him and Rachel, just when she needs him the most."Me and Earl and the Dying Girl" gives a voice to typical teen angst in the 21st century, and shows us the challenges faced by typical teens who are forced to deal with issues beyond their still-developing emotional capacity. The primary voice in the movie is Greg's. He sometimes narrates the action (speaking in language a teenager would use, such as the way the movie's title is phrased). We sometimes see brief clips (animation, voice-over and live action) of what's going on in his head. As an audience, we gradually become aware that throughout the movie, we're seeing the world through Greg's eyes. The adults around him are weird in a way that seems at least partially colored by Greg's perceptions.This film is based on the book of the same name, by first-time novelist (and the film's screenwriter) Jesse Andrews, who, in his 30s, has created teenage characters more authentic than any I've seen on film in quite a while. While other YA authors have addressed issues that are important to teens, Andrews gets to the core of who they are as people. In the movie, the title characters are powerfully portrayed, but some of the adult characterizations are sloppy and the plot takes a twist that I found offensive and inappropriate. But, overall, this is a film that is entertaining, while dealing with its subject matter (mostly) respectfully and portraying modern teenagers in a way that feels quite real, even in the midst of circumstances that, to them, probably feel anything but. "B+"

reviews.review_title: Cute Movie
reviews.content: I would have probably given this movie a 7/10, but this movie was very entertaining to me with its constant film references, making it an 8/10 in my book.While this film is visually interesting at certain times, I felt the look of the film could have been improved overall - a lot of the time scenes would look not only unsaturated, it almost looked plain gray. I guess this is probably intentional since the film deals with the gloomy topic of a "dying girl," but the unsaturated colors simply made it seem boring at parts.Going back to the introduction, you should definitely see this movie if you consider yourself to be a film buff or if you like the classics. Half of the movie is either movie references or Greg and Early actually making terrible film parodies such as "Eyes Wide Butt," "The 400 Bros," "A Sockwork Orange," and many more with hilarious titles. The sad thing is I think this reference to film is the best aspect of the film, and it barely touches on the actual story of the film.This next part is a spoiler: In my opinion, this is a very bad device the filmmakers used to make you more emotional towards the end of the film. Greg says at least twice to the audience that the "dying girl" doesn't die, but then she does. To me it wasn't even emotional - I'm not fed up with the fact that this was a lie, I just think this was done to make the ending sadder which was a stupid aspect.Overall it is a nice story if you're looking for something like "The Fault in Our Stars" but with a slightly darker tone and a lot more humor.

reviews.review_title: Brims With Smarty-Pants Wit, Whimsical Kookiness and Sincere Poignancy
reviews.content: Who needs yet another high school angsty melodrama? Who needs another cancer stricken teenager so soon after The Fault in Our Stars? Apparently we do. Brimming with smart-ass wit, whimsical kookiness and sincere poignancy, Me and Earl and the Dying Girl goes on a trajectory straight for your heart and hits its mark.High schooler Greg (Thomas Mann), who spends most of his time making parodies of classic movies with his co-worker Earl (RJ Cyler), finds his outlook forever altered after befriending a classmate (Olivia Cooke) who has just been diagnosed with cancer.The movie blasts off the starting block with some Wes Anderson quirkiness and John Hughes on-the-pulse teenage angst, and blazes a different path. How Alfonso Gomez-Rejon establishes Greg's character in the opening scenes through weird angled shots and clever purposeful narration grabbed my heart and it wasn't let go until long after the movie has ended. Soon after that sequences of parodies of classic films splashed on the screen and I was totally sold with a big silly smile on my face - Gomez-Rejon is a film nerd, just like me.The cast in the three main roles mentioned in the namesake of the film title is awesome. Their chemistry is instantly palpable. Greg embodies the narrative voice wonderfully and I saw myself in him - he feels like an alien walking around the school compound with an adverse idea to making friends. The cafeteria to him is the living hell of cliques and factions because he is not a true member to any group but a member to every group. His best friend, nope scratch that, his partner-in-crime Earl who eats and makes parodies with him is termed as his associate because of his adverse concept of the word 'friend'. Rachel, the dying girl is the living embodiment of irony - a young girl on the cusp of a bright future but crippled with a disease that prevents that from happening. Although I must iterate that the narration does reassure us twice that she doesn't die.There are many things I like about this movie and the chief amongst them is that the two principals do not fall in love. The dialogue is well-written with an air of crisp freshness and authenticity. Just watch the scene when Greg and Rachel first spoke to each other on the stairwell. It is so spot-on witty, hits a raw nerve and yet never treads the mawkishly sentimental path of ultimate maudlin. I also love how Earl is portrayed - he is a walking conundrum but how his character arc progresses is very moving. The movie goes into tearjerker mode in the final act which by that time has earned its right for that last emotional wallop. Please bring tissue.This movie won the Grand Jury Prize and the Audience Award, the same two wins Whiplash (2014) earned before landing some big nominations at the Oscars. I wouldn't say Me and Earl and the Dying Girl is as powerful but it is simply outstanding in the way it treats a serious subject matter with such a feather-like touch and humility.

reviews.review_title: Film Review: Me and Earl and the Dying Girl
reviews.content: THIS IS THE PART THAT I BEGIN MY REVIEW AND INTRODUCE THE FILM WITH A CLEVER HOOKYou would never think that a title with the words "dying girl" would be the most buzzed about film at Sundance 2015, causing a bidding war that would eventually be won by Fox Searchlight Pictures for a whopping $12 million, the largest distribution purchase in the history of the fest. But alas, Me and Earl and the Dying Girl is a true testament to the power of YA pop culture, and a young adult film infused with the current obsession with cancer- driven teen fiction. Following in the footsteps of the widely popular The Fault in Our Stars and my personal favourite cancer-comedy 50/50, Me and Earl and the Dying Girl is a mix of both, with a hint of 500 Days of Summer in for good indie measure.Thankfully, Me and Earl and the Dying Girl is miles ahead of the aforementioned Stars and is easily one of the most wryly self-aware and raucously comedic films of the year.The ironic aspect of Me and Earl is that cancer has never really been at the front-row of comedy in the real world. Although it is one of the most devastating diseases of our time, consuming the lives of many loved ones, cancer, in this instance, sets up one of the most endearing and authentic cinematic friendships seen on screen, in a very long time.Now if you are all thinking, how in the hell is a film about a very pending friendship between two boys and a girl recently diagnosed with leukaemia one of the funniest and best films of the year? All I'd have to say is "Respect the Research" and find out for yourself.THIS IS THE PART WHERE I EXPLAIN MY COMMENTARIES ON THE FILMOne of the many (and I'm talking about a ton) charms of Me and Earl is its ability to share so many universal and relatable truths to its audience. The fact remains, Rachel Kushner (Olivia Cooke) is a seventeen-year old girl who is recently diagnosed with Leukaemia. Greg Gaines (Thomas Mann) is a smart-talking, quick responding, social leper who has serious issues with the word friendship and a great appreciation for hipster and event-garde culture (including Warhol, Herzog and B-films). Earl (RJ Cyler), the innocent by-stander in all of this, is your typical high-schooler who obsesses mostly with "titties". Yet, these three unique characters and the serious and lighthearted issues they face in a small Pittsburg high school offer some of the most insightful and emotional responses from an audience in the year 2015.Based on Jesse Andrews' book of the same name, the author was able to adapt his own book into a screenplay, keeping its infectious charm and wit intact. Luckily for us, Andrews' book has been described as a book made to be read by anyone; anyone who has gone to high school, anyone who has lost someone they love, or grew up with a family, or has wondered what life is all about.Directed by Alfonso Gomez-Rejon, a sophomore feature following his debut horror film The Town That Dreaded Sundown, the film blends a very inauspicious mix of quirk at first by beginning the story with an abundance of stop-motion animation, flashbacks, and some very obvious film-school favourites including; the long take; pans; and long shots. Rejon, who began his career as a personal assistant to Martin Scorsese, shows his range as a charming director who is able to not only amp up the quirk factor, but also get the best performances from his actors and characters to help narrate the story to uncontrollable moments of laughter. Much like its main character Greg (Thomas Mann) and his inability to obtain normal friendships or accept the obvious classes created in any high school setting, Rejon embraces the main essence of Andrews' novel, loss and love and stays true to its unique nerdiness, owning every second of it.THIS IS THE PART WHERE ITALKIt was the best of times, it was the worst of times, and for the most part, Me and Earl and the Dying Girl is easily one of the most satisfying films of 2015, and not for the usual ingredients that make an indie film so great either. While most indie films are applauded and hailed for their quirky soundtracks, incredible acting discoveries, and new finds, Me and Earl has an interesting quality of brining back the old, and making it cool again. Rejon, an obvious film enthusiast and lover of classics (Criterion quality to B-movie selections) sends great satisfaction of allowing his feature of reminiscing on these classic films in a fringe- type cinematic wet dream. His rehashing, mockery yet clear praise and reference to classic films shows his great admiration and love for film as a whole. While Greg and Earl half- heartedly remake some of their favourtite films, we get a clear sense of what makes them great friends, their ability to embrace their immaturity and playfulness. Rejon pulls it off through and through, that boys will be boys, while Mann and Cyler really hit that notion out of the par throughout each scene.While death is the overwhelming factor in Me and Earl and the Dying Girl, the film becomes less about death, the tragedy of loss and the morbid reality of sadness and more a remembrance of good memories, happy times, sad times, and the emotions they easily illicit to us. Rejon easily proves himself to be a mature director playing with many depths; depths with his storytelling but mostly, the wide range of depths of the emotions he so easily controls masterfully on screen between friends.

reviews.review_title: Emotional Roller Coaster
reviews.content: The title prepared me for the ending but I wouldn't have expected to get so many laughing out loud moments. I loved this completely, especially the use of the fourth wall by Greg, the narrator.

reviews.review_title: Teenage boys: Take a date to see this one
reviews.content: I was really looking forward to this movie, but at the same time I had the feeling that it was jumping upon the dying girl bandwagon. I didn't want it to be those romantic teenage drama, such as "The Fault in Our Stars" and "If I Stay", AND IT WASN'T. The whole movie has narration by the main character, Greg, and at several he acknowledges the fact that this is not a touching romantic story. But you teenage guys out there, if you need a movie to bring a date to this is the one. Skip "Jurassic World" and take them to a movie that they will enjoy. Now you may be complaining that you want something that's not a "chick flick" and this is not a chick flick. It's told from the perspective of a guy and there were multiple times where I, as a teenage guy, laughed and I looked over to see that the girls I went with didn't get it.The movie is based upon a book, as most of our good movies are, but its a different entity. The screenplay is written by the same guy who wrote the book so don't go in expecting it to be how you pictured it when you read it. I enjoyed both and you need to look at them entirely different. Now this movie is obviously an independent film. It is filmed in a different style that helps sell the awkwardness of some scenes. It reminds me of an altered Wes Anderson style that isn't so out there. It's a little distracting at the beginning but you get used to it. If you are wanting a quirky and depressing comedy, this is the movie to go to. The teenage adults in the film help carry the story along rather than stall it. And teenage boys, take a girl to this rather than "Jurassic World".

reviews.review_title: Honest Teenage Rulebook
reviews.content: Teenagers are not innately prepared to deal with the death of a peer. Also, teenagers are sarcastic.Greg is one of these teenagers. He is marked by a self-deprecating personality and a "just getting by" attitude. Earl is his "coworker," and they remake classic films to add to their secret collection. Greg's "acquaintance" Rachel is suddenly diagnosed with leukemia, and when his mom forces him to reach out, the movie takes off.Continuously entertaining, captivating, and honest. This movie is smart, witty, and heartfelt, all thanks to the three leads. I looked forward to every shot of the movie, very inventive camera-work. While there is a lesson for everyone, this movie is absolute gold for teenagers. I am a senior in high school, and I found endless relations between myself and the characters, particularly Greg. We feel like avoiding interaction is in our best interest, staying unnoticed and invisible. Beneath all of that is a self-obsessed attitude, which is evident in Greg's occasional habit of involving himself in Rachel's story. He knows that he is special and has a gift for other eyes, his movies, and yet his immaturity still holds him back. Until the end, when the bigger picture is revealed. An important, selfless message about ourselves. And at the VERY end, we are given a refreshing idea of how stuffing our faces with schoolwork and colleges may not be of utmost importance, despite parental comments. So, SO applicable.To find any fault at all, the movie occasionally felt obsessed with its individuality in an unnecessary way. However, the outrageous differences that the movie offers might model Greg's journey, as his cloud of sarcasm healthily fades in place of real, necessary emotion. 9.5/10

reviews.review_title: A truly heartfelt movie
reviews.content: Me and Earl and the Dying Girl is a coming of age movie that is actually surprisingly really good. First off,the cast is perfect,starting by Thomas Mann who portrays the main character on the film.This guy has got a bright future ahead of him because he is really amazing on the leading role.He nails the emotions on the more dramatic scenes and also he delivers the more funny/comedic scenes too. Olivia Cooke is also really good,as the dying girl (Rachel),and so is R.J. Cyler and truly everyone else on the movie. The camera-work is also flawless,and the direction this movie takes is something special,so props to the director and the choreographer for doing a wonderful job in here. The problem with the movie is more on the pacing,because sometimes some scenes are touching and hit at the beginning but as they go along they lose their momentum because the scene simply goes on for a little too long. Nonetheless,this movie is a hit and truly stands out in the coming of age genre that is growing every day.In my honest opinion,it is not as good as The Fault In Our Stars,but it's about the same level,and maybe even better,then Paper Towns.

reviews.review_title: Gem bordering on little masterpiece
reviews.content: Well, I can't believe that a film managed to engage me this much. I always hope and yet never expect movies to be that good. There's so much try-hard rubbish now.Somehow, this managed to remain exceptional, despite being a 'coming of age' movie. Completely lacking sentimentalism, perfectly cast, excellent acting.The first couple of minutes left me wondering if it was going to be stupid, but this was a really wonderful, clever work that never felt immature or cutesy.

reviews.review_title: A cool and a heart touching story
reviews.content: While the first half of the movie depicts comedy and the immature and witty teenage nature,the story takes you deep into thoughts and touches you in deep bottom.After "Forestgump",I got an opportunity to watch a sensationally good movie yet underrates @ 8.1. As far as characters are concerned,the best part of the film is that its a beautiful film,with no characters evidently visible and the story line takes the front seat.Though the subject is a very old one compared to the likes of notebook,it is the screenplay that brings the difference,director has taken enough care to ensure that the teenage subject he is dealing with is intact and he never missed the line of over depicting emotions for that age.Overall,I must say watch this movie.There is no reason to miss this beautifully narrated story.

reviews.review_title: Three words; SEE THIS FILM
reviews.content: Me and Earl and the Dying Girl is simply amazing. Funny, moving and wonderfully weird, it is everything a great coming of age film should be and has to be one of the best films of 2015 and of its sub genre.The screenplay was written by the author of the book this film is based off. The best book to screen adaptations are often written by the authors themselves and this film is living proof of this. The story is deeply meaningful and funny without being pretentious like some young adult coming of age films come across (*cough* Paper Towns *cough*).The direction and cinematography rip up the rule book creating unique shots that together create a spectacular vision that won Glee and American Horror Story director Alfonso Gomez-Rejon, the Grand Jury and Audience award at Sundance for the film and rightly so.The Characters in the film are great and relatable to teenagers today (well at least relatable to me). My only critique for the film being that I would have liked to see more of Earl as he is one of if not the funniest character in the film, being a man of few words, Dem Tities. Also the film is called me and EARL and the dying girl so I would have expected a bit more screen time for a character who has top billing.Overall Me and Earl and the Dying Girl is a near perfect movie, a film that will make you laugh as well as cry from its experimental opening to its heart breaking/ warming ending. I highly recommend you watch this film as it is a modern master piece and to me goes down as one of my personal favourite films

reviews.review_title: Beautiful,Heart warming and Colorful
reviews.content:
This movie is one of the most realistic and best coming of the age movies ever made. The cinematography, performances and dialogue are an absolute delight.
If you liked "Spectacular Now" you will definitely like this.PS: Watch this movie if you are in a really frustrated or bad mood

reviews.review_title: You better appreciate it ...
reviews.content: Yes! This is the most depressing movie since 'Schindler's List', and yes, I haven't cried that much since I've watched the Grave- Speech-Scene from 'The Fault in Our Stars' the second time.So obviously, no, if you're looking for a light-hearted feel-good movie, or even a movie that makes you leave with a crying and a laughing eye, this is not it, you will be leaving with both eyes crying. So what's the point? There's a scene where the teacher tells how he realized stories from his dad, after he died. He didn't quite spell out the meaning of the story, but it would be something like this: You better appreciate people why they are still around, because even if you think you know a person, know what they think, how they feel ... Trust me, you don't.

reviews.review_title: Sad and awkward meet in one movie.
reviews.content: This is a comically dark movie. It gets boring sporadically; to clarify, it wasn't as much captivating at the beginning, but became touching in the last scenes. I advise you, not to expect much out of it, so you don't get frustrated, but I can say it's an overall above average movie. This film deals with loss, particularly, losing people to diseases like cancer. The film is an admixture of ludicrousness and melancholy which is super hard to be done, On the positive side, I feel elated now that I've watched this as it had a lot of real-life events going on. The filming photography was marvelous, and the overall visual effect made this amusing to watch (colors, camera angles, editing) not to mention the carved pieces of art. Thomas Mann perfectly played his role by doing a fascinating character with a reluctance to be a real friend with anyone except for Earl he is a socially awkward teenager with a quirky personality; on the other hand, Olivia Cooke was even better; I believe that's due to her wistful facial features I was convinced she is a cancer patient. Furthermore, the movie touches upon many common topics like fitting in school and applying to college, and all the pressure that come with that, like anxiety and self-loathing, but there is a lot to like in the way Mann comes to realize that he is not quite as defeatist as he once thought gives you the sense of self-discovering while being attached to people. Given the key themes of terminal illness and death, I reckon the tenor of the scenario has been clear, it was not to let yourself detached from social life no matter how hard it gets.

reviews.review_title: me earl and the dying girl spoilers
reviews.content: Gregg is a young boy in high school that is okay with everybody he has one friend called earl but he doesn't like calling him his friend, Rachel has a group of friends that she hangs around with a school and so Gregg and Rachel never used to speak. Gregg comes home from school one day and his mum comes in to tell him Rachel has cancer. Gregg and Rachel aren't really friends at this point and is forced by his mum to go see her. they start becoming friends and Rachel finds out that him and earl make silly films and so she starts watching them with him... Sadly Rachel and Gregg don't get together and just say friends.Gregg and Rachel have an argument. Rachel was thinking about stopping her treatment and Gregg is upset about it. Gregg and Rachel don't speak for a few days until Greggs mum comes in to tell him Rachel is back in hospital, he finally goes to see her on the night of the prom and she is his date and finally he shows her the film he and earl made for her, while watching the film Rachel starts getting sick and Gregg rushes to get a nurse and he is rushed out the room. before shortly she goes into a coma and passes away. At her wake he finds out new things about Rachel that he never knew before he also find a letter to his college as he was accepted but then his work drop as he spent all winter with Rachel and so the didn't want to take him anymore, Rachel was the one who wrote the letter for him and to show the college something that she knows but earl didn't, she tell him that he is kind and caring and is the only person that truly made her smile and that he was pretty scared of going to college. finally the movies ends with Rachel speaking and telling you the letter and Gregg taking her pillow ha-ha (you'll understand when you watching it) and the college book he gave her (you'll understand that when you watch it as well)

reviews.review_title: A Perfect coming of age Masterpiece
reviews.content: This movie is phenomenal by every perspective, the plot, the acting (mainly Olivia Cooke, she did her role perfectly), the Ending made me cry like hell.

reviews.review_title: Very satisfying
reviews.content: I liked the style of this movie with some narration in parts by the main male lead character Greg. The first half of the movie and the relationship between the three leads is kinda predictable, but do hang on, because the story gets meatier and draws you in to the point where you really feel something for all of the characters. I could relate to Greg's guide to surviving the trials of High School - I saw a lot of myself in him!! The subject matter is handled superbly - not over-sentimental in a manipulative way to feel sorry for the Rachel character. Good acting and direction. I very much enjoyed the movie (even at my age!)- parts of it will resonate with most of us and take us back to what life was like in High School. I wouldn't say you must go and see this at movie theater, but well worth checking out on your media of choice. No great surprises in the movie, just a gentle, tender story portrayed beautifully. The older you are, you've probably experienced something like this in your life with a family member or close friend, but for younger ones, this is potentially life changing.

reviews.review_title: Genuine display of growth, grief and friendship
reviews.content: Don't get me wrong, a coming of age story about an awkward teenager and his eccentric best friend dealing with a dying classmate isn't something that may shock you. What this film does that sets itself apart from all the other coming of age stories is the heart and in the way it's presented.No scene is boring due to the way that it is shown. From panning that begins on a high view and ending in a sideway portrait angle, it always manages to give personality to a movie that is largely surrounded about the heart of Greg's quirkiness and interest in indie film making.Through the navigation of Greg's awkward journey, we meet Rachel, the dying girl. Long uninterrupted shots of their interactions makes for a compelling progression of their friendship that doesn't try to force romance as we see a genuine take on a friendship that was forcefully began but bloomed due to their unique similarities and context.Having watched this movie 4 times now at very different ages, it seems to be relatable at different stages of my life. I would think this is due to the screenwriting and performances that makes for a genuine display of growth, grief and acceptance of death and friendship.

reviews.review_title: Thought Provoking for your Teen......and you
reviews.content: Well this flick is surprisingly funny for the subject matter. Really interesting use of some folks you don't see in films all the time; Molly Shannon, Nick Offerman.I would say that it is a family film with some language and such. Also, it is inspiring. If you like indie films and have seen a lot, you will like the references to all of them! Werner Herzog really gets razzed!The title tells something of the story but it is a coming of age film. Teenagers never realize, well I did not, that the world doesn't revolve around you and your problems. Greg wakes up and truly gives something of himself....wholly without reservation. The thing is, Rachel shows herself to be quite a human being too. If it is to much of a moral plot....or too inline with a story of learning how things should go, oh well, I still really like it!I really like the mocking of indie cinema.....by a film that is kind of in that genre. Thomas Mann and Rj Cyler will be going places after this!

reviews.review_title: Me and Earl and the Dying Girl
reviews.content: Greg, an awkward high school student, is entering his senior year. He is a misfit who carefully navigates his way through each of his school's student groups without standing out. He and his best friend Earl spend most of their time making parody films together (list of parody films and obvious spoilers). One day, he learns from his mother that his childhood friend, Rachel, is diagnosed with acute myelogenous leukemia. His mother forces him to try to spend time with her to make her feel better. The two have an awkward start to their new friendship with neither seemingly wanting each other's company but it eventually grows and develops as she begins to fall for his quirky personality. The film primarily serves as his story of how he spends his time with Rachel and thus it is told from his perspective and he narrates it.This film is a coming-of-age story as he deals with his last year of high school and decides what he wants to do about his future while living with his overbearing parents and hanging out and making films with his best friend. The film covers a lot of subject matter, it's a high school comedy, it's a drama, and it's an experimental film all in one and it does them all very well. It explores high school social structure in a smart and original way that everyone would expect that reminded me of when I went to high school (jocks, nerds, geeks, goths, etc). The film does a great job of not sensationalizing terminal illness as it is just the secondary or even tertiary plot line and the film's treatment of her friendship with Greg is both darkly funny and realistically bleak. The bulk of it focuses on Greg's relationships either with Rachel, Earl, his parents or with Earl and his history teacher, Mr. McCarthy. The writing and execution is elite quality. Each character seem are grounded and depicted realistically. Parent and child relationships and peer relationships all are captured in humorous and touching ways. The dramatic elements of the film don't come across as cliché or cheesy thanks to the acting and the writing that I've previously mentioned. I applaud the imagination involved in the parody films which Greg and Earl make as they are cheesy, funny, and full of charm with the purposefully bad acting and some nice stop-motion animation. This comes from the fact that they make them by themselves with the smallest of budgets. I would definitely not mind if they could be released in any form, maybe online. The actor who plays Greg, Thomas Mann, definitely carries this film with his performance and I was pleasantly surprised seeing that I have not heard of him before (quick IMDb search). The three main actors had excellent chemistry together on top of the original script kept me laughing and entertained for most of the film. For those who may be unsure, this not one of those pretentious YA book-based movies. It is a smartly written, well acted film and is one of the best films of the year.keithlovesmovies.com

reviews.review_title: Worth your while
reviews.content: Looking for solid drama what will put a smile on your face , this one is for you! I honestly wasn't expecting this film to be that good , i haven't heard about it at all but luckily stumbled upon it yesterday. The plot of the film is not so original yet it is very interesting and full of touching and funny moments .Also i have to mention the great directors job on this film , i really like how it all was shot and put together at the end. It was also really nice to see a younger generation of talented actors in this one.I must mention also the awesome soundttack. Overall i would totally recommend this one to anyone , its not boring as most of the dramas these days plus it has its funny moments and who doesn't like to laugh a little bit.

reviews.review_title: I thought it was absolutely fantastic!
reviews.content: First off, I want to say that I did not read the book. But I loved the movie none the less! I found it to be a very strong story and the structure of the plot was well laid out. It's been quite a while since I've seen a movie that had me so involved with the characters lives and world that sometimes I forgot I was watching a film. I found the humor very pleasing with a realistic feeling. At times catching me off guard and abruptly laughing out loud (sometimes very loud:) the actors did a tremendous job! The relationship between both main characters was heart warming and complicated and I found the comedic relief from supporting actor RJ Cyler a perfect trio. The only thing stopping me from giving this movie a 10 is the cinematography in the beginning. No complaints about the muted colors but there were a few scenes where I found it to be too wide of a lens which distracted me overall, along with interesting choice of landscape to portrait to landscape transition from one location to another. I commend and respect director of photography Chung-hoon Chung for doing something different. But to me I found it a bit odd. Also, I like the use of distance used between both Rachel and Greg in the beginning of the movie but I felt that shots where they were to far apart was overdone. I do understand the visual metaphor of the relationships between the characters and I think that it was used well. I just felt that it could have been used a little less. But overall those were very minor for me in an otherwise great movie! Hence the 9 star rating!

reviews.review_title: A believable, unconventional movie...until the end
reviews.content: BIG SPOILERSThe ending didn't completely ruin it for me--I still thought it was a great movie. I loved the dialog and the acting. But the ending kept me from enjoying it as much as I would have otherwise. Based on Greg's denials in the narration, I was hoping that Me and Earl would break the mold and actually allow the "dying" girl to live. After all, the survival rate for childhood leukemia is in the high 90s! But no, in the end the movie reverts back to all the usual dying girl clichés, especially during the overwrought final video scene.In my opinion, using an unreliable narrator in this case was a cheap trick. Yes, I know that there are lots of unreliable narrators like Greg in fiction, The Life of Pi being a famous example. But most unreliable narrators are either immature, mentally ill, or mentally handicapped, or they have some really strong reason for lying to the audience (for example, to cover up a crime or to make a central point as in The Life of Pi). It also bothered me that the screenwriter never gave Greg the opportunity to tell Rachel how he really felt. I thought it was going to happen in the final video, but it didn't.

reviews.review_title: Best film 2015
reviews.content: This film is the best film I seen all year, I smiled laughed and even cried. It was a great film to watch for teens/young adults especially. Anyone can identify with the premises presented especially wanting to be invisible (something most teens wish for) at least I could identify with it. The cast was very good and supported each other well. This could contend of Oscars as it was really well done. It is at least a very good coming of age film. The film seems not to be persuading you in to believing something. The fact that it's not all about sex, like so many teen films seem to be, is a big plus for this film. Also there are not religious overtones also it's just a fantastic film.

reviews.review_title: A Sockwork Orange, enough said
reviews.content: Me and Earl and the dying Girl is directed by Alfonso Gomez-Rejon and written by Jesse Andrews. It stars Thomas Mann, Olivia Cooke, and RJ Cyler along with Nick Offerman, Molly Shannon, and Katherine C. Hughes.This movie revolves around Greg(Thomas Mann), a high schooler whose quest is to stay as secluded as possible and amateur film director, as he befriends a cancer ridden girl, Rachel(Olivia Cooke). This leads him and his best friend Earl(RJ Cyler) to make a film for Rachel.I love this movie. It was amazing! Those seven word usually don't get said when I talk about a Coming-of-age tale. Most are either too dramatic or too uninteresting. This movie found its footing from the first one minute with the opening gag. This is amazing considering how badly the setup could've gone if done poorly but instead it was short and sweet. As the opening scene fades we are treated fine performances across the board. Nick Offerman, Molly Shannon and Katherine C. Hughes give great performances that add so much depth to the movie. Thomas Mann offers possibly the best performance of his career as he demonstrates all of Greg's vulnerabilities and strengths without making him too weak of a character or too strong of a character. Though Mann was excellent two people completely outshine him. RJ Cyler delivers an awe inspiring performance as Earl even though he barely speaks throughout the movie runtime. But the best performance by a long shot was Olivia Cooke. Cooke's portrayal as Rachel is beautiful, depressing, uplifting and overall masterful. She doesn't try to be a tearjerker but with that stated it hard not to tear up at her performance. Moving away from the performances lies the writing. The direction was fine but the writing had something to it. After I finished watching it I went home and checked who wrote it and to my surprise it was Jessie Andrews, writer of the book. One can really tell something is different about the movie from the start, a little more care is placed into it than other teen movies. Overall this is in my top three best movie of the year and I'm not sure how many more movie I can say that about. I implore you go see this movie! Me and Earl and the Dying girl Gets an A or a 9/10

reviews.review_title: Both hilarious and heartbreaking
reviews.content: I very much enjoyed this film. It is full of humor, relatable characters, and heartfelt moments. Overall, I highly recommend this film for anyone looking to laugh and/or cry.8/10...but that's just like, my opinion, man# Of Times Watched: Once

reviews.review_title: Hilarious, and heartbreakingly real in the best of ways.
reviews.content: This may sound like every other coming of age story, but i assure you, it is not.Greg (Thomas Mann) is the kind of kid in your high school you didn't know existed. Socially awkward, anxiety ridden and self loathing to a fault. He's the outsider, preferring to remain invisible by refraining from any significant relationships with people. Greg is the outsider most of us probably were at one point or another, and he likes to keep it that way.Enter Rachel (Olivia Cooke), the dying girl.Rachel's been diagnosed with leukemia, so Greg's mom forces him to spend some time with her. It will be a "nice thing", she says.Of course, Greg has no desire to hang out with a stranger while Rachel has no interest in attaining pity from anyone. They hang out anyway to appease their parents, and end up forming an unlikely friendship that develops wonderfully in ways you might not expect.And yes this all sounds like every single coming of age story we've seen, but its been gifted with terrific performances by both Mann and Cooke that lend real heart and authenticity to their characters. This is also not a manipulative tearjerker Ala "The Fault In Our Stars", where the boy falls madly in love with a girl and ends up in a tragic romance.Instead of diving into a bowl of generic angst, our heroines face it head on with off kilter, deadpan humor. The result is a film that feels refreshingly real, striking a fantastic balance between its hilariously off beat characters and earnest drama. Its the best Wes Anderson movie Wes Anderson never directed, and i unabashedly love it.So I could sit here and tell you how poignant the film is, how its funny and heartfelt all at the same time. How its one of the best films of the year. But how boring would that be? I would be doing the film a disservice by spoiling its moments. Like most films, it has to be seen to be understood.Yes, coming of age stories are a dime a dozen these days. But every once in a blue moon, a movie like "Me and Earl and the Dying Girl" comes along to remind us how powerful and affecting movies can be. So if you haven't already, please give this one a shot. It might just become a new favorite of yours.

reviews.review_title: The End Is Important In All Things
reviews.content: Me and Earl and The Dying girl at first glance has everything you would expect to see from glancing at the title. There's Greg & his best friend Earl, your regular trying- to-survive high school kids, who are captivated by old movies and shooting short- film re-enactments of their favorite scenes. There's Mr McCarthy, almost a farther like figure to Greg & Earl, a brutal hipster looking English teacher who lets them hide and watch movies in his office. And then There's Rachel, an innocent girl who is set to pass away, way to soon. Or is she? In it's essence, Me and Earl and The Dying girl is a sweet, sincere and brutally honest portrayal of a coming of age teenager, who has to deal with something that no one quite knows how to handle. We see Greg in constant denial, unable to deal with the fact that Rachel is most likely going to pass away. He is even unable to tell us, the viewers, that this is what will happen. Alfonso Gomez-Rejon lets us watch a big share of this movie through a lens of optimism by specifically stating that Rachel will get better. Thus we take our guard down, letting ourselves really indulge and start deeply caring for Rachel. This is in no way a suspense move in a way to spear the viewer from crying for a 100 minutes. It is genuinely a state of mind that any teenager of Greg's age would have in a similar situation. Any human maybe. It is in our nature to hope for the best, constantly. Greg heroically and willingly becomes a friend to Rachel, he genuinely thinks that she will get better, even during her last moments. However this turn of events also makes us pay attention to small details, that otherwise would have been ingrained in trying to cope with a death of a teenager. We deeply analyze how hard this situation is for Rachel's mother, we can focus more on the relationship between Earl and Greg as well as nostalgically listen to Mr McCarthy's life stories and lessons. Alfonso Gomez-Rejon began his career as personal assistant to Martin Scorsese, Nora Ephron, Robert De Niro and Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu. One can really notice Innaritu in this picture, especially towards the end, during long patient scenes of Greg and Rachel coupled with moody sound scores from Greg's short-film. Rejon does a wonderful job. The film is truly funny, heartbreaking and human.In watching Greg's last short film, along with Greg and Rachel, we realize just how meaningless life truly is, that in it's nature, it is a simple compilation of frames and sounds. Rachel's death still comes as a slight shock to the viewer, just like it did to Greg. We, too, had hoped that a miracle will happen any minute, even as evidence increasingly suggested otherwise.Throughout his journey, Greg will learn how to make compromises, learn to care about someone, make new friends, lose existing ones and finally experience an inevitable loss of someone he loved. All of these events will undoubtedly 'shape' Greg as a human being, as he will swear never to forget Rachel, The dying girl.

reviews.review_title: Well made, well acted, teenage tearjerker.
reviews.content: This movie was a pleasant surprise, and a much stronger offering than much of the dreck floating about these days. The movie starts with Greg, a senior high schooler who has a love for film, explaining how he keeps such a low profile that he belongs to no "groups" commonly found in high school - jocks, nerds, goths, etc. The downside of his low profile is an almost complete lack of friends, the one exception being his colleague in film - Earl. Greg's mom "forces" him to hang out with Rachel, who has been diagnosed with leukemia (what flavour we never learn), and what begins as an obligation soon turns into the focus of his life. Alongside all the teenage drama we are treated to the parody movies that Greg and Earl make, some of which are quite humorous, others just blah. Still, the film-making shows Greg and Earl are actually artistes who have emotions that run deep, and they are not the non- participants in life that they originally seem. A problem the movie suffers is this paradox - Greg is at once a hyper-deep, emotional boy and a clueless, shallow buffoon. His petty, unfeeling actions when he learns that Rachel has decided to die are out of character. It's as though he hasn't witnessed her struggle and pain throughout months of treatment. His heartless dismissal of her at her time of need makes him much less likable and hard to relate to - does he not realize this is her decision and is he not a true friend? Anyhow, there is some ham-fisted over acting and some really garbage "art films" complete with black and white slow motion smiling, tears rolling, stop motion, etc. that make the viewer want to stop watching (even though we understand these are DEEP, EMOTIONAL, ARTISTIC films). Despite this the movie succeeds, and Greg emerges on the other side of Rachel's death as a better person, who understands her better. He keeps learning about her after her death, which is the main premise of the film - as he still learns about her, his relationship with her grows, showing us the viewer that death is not the end. The movie treats Earl almost as an after-thought, and both the character and actor deserve more. Likewise Greg's parents and teachers. Anyhow, Olivia Cooke does a great job and the film succeeds largely on the strength of her. Not a masterpiece, but quite good and worth a watch.

reviews.review_title: Shooting "To Become a Man" Takes A While..Me and Earl and The Dying Girl
reviews.content: The texture is a little bit 1980s and a little bit 1990s.A young boy's agony of his process of leaving the boyhood and becoming a man. The places, semiology, plans, settings and everything else is nostalgic in fact, just like trying to show us the intellectual and numb situation of the youth in America is predominant except the ignorant and numb majority of them. As I mentioned the texture including the 90's or 80's waves in it, the depiction of intellectuality of the teenagers and their awareness of human relationships even if they are senseless, could have been possibly shot only by these nostalgic waves considering today's world's teenage attractions based on the popular culture.The movie's movement towards to cult and classic Hollywood films especially in a perspective of the interest of young people, gives the parents and the youth hope for their future responsibility capacities. The context of the movie ironically and secretly reveals the semiology that some idiotic reality shows or senseless social media-based relationships does exist dominantly especially in the pop-culture teenage world. But the clear message is somehow teenagers who have troubled social life is just and illusion, it's and will naturally be very easy to break their robotic acts just like every one of us lived this course by attending to real life relationships full of heartbreaks, deaths, illnesses or maybe separations with our beloved ones.The movie's another interesting component besides the texture of nostalgia, beautiful editing or direction of photography and etc. is the script's purity which was ornate with teenagers' humoristic and glimpsing dialogues, acts and the pure sufferings in their adulthood process in a mixture of beautiful eclectic way. Just like adulthood process living a teenage boy or a girl.My empathy when I was coming to the end has raised time by time and my thinkings of what if all these happened to me in young age, terrified me and to be honest I have considered myself lucky for not becoming a responsible adult in a strict rapid process. Maybe these young hearts' lives reminded me my short films that I shot at the age of 14 in the influence of the other classic and cult films in an humoristic way just like they do in the film.And I also admit that the Midnight Cowboy re-make scene caused the double feel down effect to me both by this movie's scene and the first time I watched the Midnight Cowboy when I was at their age.The movie has satisfied me in every way. I recommend you for just going back to your school times with a wave of nostalgia, and to emphasize today's kids complications of life with lot more responsibility and to see how they live short term childhood by the forcement of the tragedies or responsibilities imposed to them whether they want to or don't want to.

reviews.review_title: The funnier Fault in our Stars
reviews.content: Me and Earl and the Dying Girl is the 2015 Grand Jury prize winner from the Sundance Film Festival. It follows in the steps of Whiplash which won the 2014 Grand Jury prize. It follows the story of Greg (Thomas Mann) who is forced by his mother (Connie Britton) to become friends with a girl from his school, Rachel (Olivia Cooke) after she is diagnosed with cancer. Greg is joined by his "co-worker" Earl (RJ Cyler) to create a film for Rachel to "do something good for her". The first thing to note is the comedy in the movie. Considering it says "Dying Girl" in the title, you'd expect and be okay if it employed a sadder register for the entirety of the movie. But it leaves the whole sad portion for the third act of the film. It rides the thin line of being quirky without being irksome which is important because of the tendency for indie-inflected films to become quite snobby for the most part. The stand out performance is of the character of Earl by RJ Cyler. A relative unknown, he is by far the funniest part of the film even though the film takes a focus on Greg and tells the story from his point of view. However, I would've liked it much better had Earl had the bigger role in the movie over Greg, as Greg's character is something that has been seen in other films in the past. The performance of Rachel by Olivia Cooke was very heartfelt and was a performance that you would connect to if you've ever known someone to have befallen due to cancer. Her initial response to her diagnosis is a very "teen" response where she's like "whatever". But as the plot progresses and her health deteriorates, Rachel isn't afraid to voice her displeasure with the disease and the people around her as well. A great little gag in the movie are the parody films having play-on titles based on the classic films of all time. For example, A Sockwork Orange for A clockwork Orange etc. For any cinephile out there, it's something to be appreciated even if those movies "sucked", in the protagonist's words. Because of the plot, there is a very easy comparison to be made with the 2014 young adult film "The Fault in our Stars". However, the register for this film is very "I hate people" in a funny way and the central relationship between Me and Earl and the Dying Girl is what grounds the movie. This movie passes and graduates high school and gets a B+.

reviews.review_title: Me and Earl and the dying girl is a different, soulful take on the coming-of-age-genre.
reviews.content: Me and Earl and the dying girl is a different, soulful take on the coming-of-age-genre-though muddled up by the melancholia of its characters, still is able to sell its brand: strong and meaningful friendships.It's not as if it snubs some of the high school elements surrounding it: hot girls, future college applications and so on. But the specific objective of the director is crystal clear: "let's make a high school film that doesn't fall into the romantic or comedy genre" even when there are temptations to sway it to either side. And the result is a slowly-paced, at-times-boring-film that you only begin to appreciate when you realize the initial reason for the build up-especially in the last thirty minutes. Thomas Mann who plays Greg makes up for an interesting character when we meet him in the film: keeping a low key by avoiding publicity stunts and blending in into every caucus. But however important, somehow self-centred and alone he is, his development and significance to the plot of the film comes as a result of his forced meeting with the "dying girl". I saw a review which compared the film to 2014's "The Fault in our Stars". True, in the sense there are similar themes between the two films: the part about a character who is suffering from a terminal disease. But I can also remember going into 30 minutes in this film and saying to myself: Oh! this looks like "The perks of being a wall flower" when looking at it from an angle that there aren't much cheerful moments in this film. The characters are either sad or wallow in self pity. And even characters like Earl, where nothing much is revealed about him, he still carries this posture of having issues. The most touching scenes in the film come during Jon Bernthal's one minute speech about learning more about a person after they are dead than when they are alive. Entertainment wise, this film fails. Audience looking for thrills and sporadic twists should avoid this. It is boring, very. But the affirmative of the film are the camera work, the off-beat milieu in suburban Pittsburgh- the faded cinematography also. All the above characteristics aim to some way resemble (Birdman)- considering that both main characters are film makers. Finally, the most important thing I see myself liking about this film is the character development of the main character Greg. The film starts with him writing a book and the chapters of that book are laid out in chapters for the whole film. Interestingly, each chapter serves as a learning opportunity for Greg. And though the director bypasses how he puts that learning experience to use. Still, there is this lingering feeling that his experiences are going to be in important tool in his life making decisions. Moreover, the human-to-human interactions are natural-highlighting on the highs and lows of everyday relationship. And though one of those interactions is with the "dying girl" (played by Olivia Cooke)-zero attempts are made to make us feel pity for her.
