reviews.review_title: Took me back...
reviews.content: This movie was a beautiful tale of a young boy that has shut himself out of all emotions only to find one person that is able to draw it out of him. I laughed, I cried, I cheered. It also took me back to the days I was in High-School. The creativity and complexity of each character keep you locked in. I found myself truly caring about each individual character, and even saw some of myself, friends, and family members in them.The style and tone of the movie make it wonderful to view. Many unique camera angles and intimate shots. I just loved the overall feel during the movie, and was left with a feeling of peace once it was finished. I truly enjoyed and highly recommend.

reviews.review_title: One of the my personal favourite films of the year!
reviews.content: When first watching the trailer for this film half a year ago I had high hopes and was one of the most anticipated films that I wanted to go see along with many others. Keeping a sad story so light and humerus is very challenging but this film I thought blended it so well together with excellent performances with the main characters of Thomas Mann as Greg, RJ Cyler as Earl and Olivia Cooke as Rachel. There was great chemistry between the cast and loved the relationship they develop over time. The plot of making friends with a dying girl would not be very upbeat and uplifting but the way it was carried out was very well done. The cinematography of the film was amazing to watch every shot and transition was perfect an really appreciated the way it was filmed. This was something I would look to use in my future with filming.I did like the narration on the film but however I think it did give away some plot points or made you think about the ending way too soon even though some of it was to mislead you. I would of preferred it to be more just kept to how the film plays out. There are many young adult films out there with similar stories like fault in our stars for instance but this film is up there with the top of them for sure. This film should get recognition through awards but the film is great and more people should go see it!

reviews.review_title: Wow! Totally overwhelmed
reviews.content: I don't usually make reviews when I've just finished the movie but in this case I prefer to do it with my tears on my cheeks already. This is a superb, awesome, incredible, sensitive and touching movie. I'm literally crying like a baby and I haven't had this feeling with a movie for years and years! Let's talk about the movie. The film has his own rhythm and step by step you will see yourself in such spiral of feelings that it will be impossible stop watching it. You will have weird sensations along the movie. On one hand you will want stop it immediately. On the other hand, the feeling inside yourself will be so immense that you will realize you could be watching this movie eternally.I cannot do another thing than recommending you Me and Earl and dying girl. You will not regret it at all. This one is that kind of film that cannot be consider as a masterpiece but without hesitation it has everything for becoming one of your favorite movies. Be ready and get some tissues before pushing the play button.

I honestly didn't think this would happen. A film, based on a teen romance book, about a girl with cancer, managed to be original and heartwarming. Now, I was sort of aware of this film before it came out. It was a huge sundance hit, and I believe I saw one trailer. I recall being extremely underwhelmed. However, director Alfonso Gomez-Rejon has crafted something that is much more than a romance or a high school movie. It's a tender salute to classic foreign cinema with enough compelling and quirky characters to make a Wes Anderson movie jealous. Greg(Thomas Mann) is a regular high-school kid, with odd parents and no real ambitions in life. He makes stop-motion films with his friend Earl(RJ Cycler) all around the town. They are all purposely crappy riffs on classics. From Breatheless to Clockwork Orange to Apocalypse Now, these stop-motion films are fantastic, and every time I caught a glimpse of one I found myself smiling from ear to ear. Whoever designed these(and the various other stop motion stuff we see in the film) deserves a bonus. Anyway, Greg's life is turned upside down when he meets Rachel(Olivia Cooke) who has cancer. He grows close to her, and soon he is trying to make a film for has a gift. The stars chemistry is solid, and in a great scene, he writes his college application as Werner Herzog. The film's depiction of high school is also refreshing. Sure there's the generic "teen movie voice-over" but the film doesn't try to "tell it like it is." It allows itself to be over-the-top. Because of this, it feels more real than most films of this nature. Overall though, the romance is definitely the weakest link because we've seen it all before. Luckily, the filmmakers know this. The direction definitely isn't perfect. There's a couple abrupt changes in tone, and Rejon's camera movements(brought over from American Horror Story) can get a little nauseating. However, Rejon has used a stale genre to create a completely unique filmgoing experience. That's a feat that deserves praise.

reviews.review_title: Quirky, emotional, funny and heartfelt.
reviews.content: Me and Earl and the Dying Girl centres around the story of high school student Greg (Thomas Mann), an every-man who enjoys making amateur parody films of classics with his 'co-worker' Earl (RJ Cyler) and his relationship with the eponymous dying girl Rachel (Olivia Cooke). Upon learning that Rachel has contracted leukaemia, Greg's mother (Connie Britton) forces him to spend time with Rachel, the two soon begin to bond and become friends, a friendship that goes deeper once Earl introduces Rachel to their amateur films and the duo are persuaded to make a film for her. The emotional core of this film is really in the chemistry of the two leads, Thomas Mann and Olivia Cooke, two relative up and comers who deliver pitch perfect performances and really help to keep the film entertaining in it's many humorous moments but also hit the right dramatic notes when the film begins to tug on the heartstrings.Full credit to screenwriter Jesse Andrews (who also wrote the novel this film is based on) for crafting a story so charming and heartfelt that you cannot help but feel connected in and drawn to these characters. The dialogue is witty and clever whilst never falling into clichés, rather it remains very self aware, especially during Greg's numerous (and hilarious) monologues. There is something so real and natural about the script that really enable us as the audience to fully become immersed in the film and it's world.Props as well to the rest of the ensemble; RJ Cyler, Connie Britton, Nick Offerman, Molly Shannon, Jon Bernthal and Katherine C. Hughes all deliver truly wonderful performances alongside Mann and Cooke whilst never feeling like they are being completely overshadowed by the two leads.The film is beautifully shot with some extremely clever shots and camera movements, think Wes Anderson style cinematography! The score/soundtrack matches every scene beautifully and never feels unnatural in any way, it really helps to craft the beauty of many scenes and also help set the tone perfectly.But when you get right down to it, the film really is about one thing; friendship. The joy of having friends and having people to spend your time with and talk to about life and it's many struggles, and trust me - there are some truly heartbreaking struggles for the characters, the title of the film alone makes that pretty clear. This is a truly beautiful little film that is equal parts sad and uplifting. Storytelling at its most beautiful.

reviews.review_title: Edearing Film Overall
reviews.content: Saw this film reluctantly and while the message is oh so sweet, I don't think it's reflective of the self-centered nature of teenagers, at least in my experience. Of course, there are always exceptions and these characters reflect the exception and not the rule where teenagers are concerned IMO.I enjoyed how things were tied together in the end like a cascade of ah-har moments and the I love how the message which the history teacher tried to teach at one moment of the film in trying to help his student comes to light at the end of the film. Well done.Interesting that there were no teens in the theater...only adults who clearly all loved the film. Teens, who paid attention, could benefit from the ideas in this film for sure. I did ultimately enjoy the film and found it uplifting. It did tug at my heartstrings and tear ducts. Altogether worthwhile film to see.

reviews.review_title: Its hard not to like this film
reviews.content: Me and Earl and the Dying Girl - Honestly, I went into this film expecting a light hearted comedy with an happy ending like the film 50/50. But this film took me by surprise. It starts off as a light hearted comedy, but slowly turns into a touching and soulful film.Though this is not the greatest film one would ever watch, it still is very hard not to like this film when its over. The success of this film is that you start feeling for the characters in it, and you are able to connect with them. A Bittersweet and kind of feel good film.Me and Earl and the Dying Girl is a 2015 American comedy-drama film directed by Alfonso Gomez-Rejon and written by Jesse Andrews, based on Andrews' 2012 debut novel of the same name.

reviews.review_title: take that john green
reviews.content: when i was fifteen, my best friend was diagnosed with lung cancer. I exactly how a teenage sarcastic cinophile (i know, spelled wrong) would handle it. Especially when he dropped over a third of his body weight and lost all his hair, there was a definite elephant in the room. He didn't want to talk about it, it occupies every waking moment of his life. I didn't want to talk about it, its beyond uncomfortable. So what did we do. We had our stupid jokes that few people would get and only we could laugh at. Some in poor taste (geez, you got out of the history final? How long are you going to keep milking the cancer card?) but exactly the sort of thing that makes us (him most of all) laugh our asses off.This is the power of this film. These characters act like real teenagers. When faced with an unspeakable horror, they deal with it. They don't deal with it all that well but how many kids their age do you know that actually would? How many adults handle the big c maturely? Its a film with a quirky style and that might be a little off putting at first but you just have to embrace it. The quirk is meant to add character, not to substitute for substance. It is a film that will ring every last tear out of you and it will have your stomach hurting form laughter. The most amazing part is how well it blends these two powers. Every laugh and every tear is earned.

reviews.review_title: Perfect movie ruined by one comment
reviews.content: SPOILER in this review. Do not read if you have not watched. We have all watched movies where a main cast member dies. This is in fact very common. Having watched thousands of movies this is the first time a movie has pulled away from itself to tell the viewer the fate of a key person. That is something I could have been find with, but finding out this fate was in fact a lie was too much in my view. It pushed me to the point of writing this fast review on a lunch break when I could be wasting time on Facebook. Not only would I not watch this movie again, but I will not watch anything directed in whole or part by the same person. You have to have a level of trust that a director is going to tell good story and this lie about such a key portion of this movie was too much. Take this out of the movie and you have a solid 9/10 rating. With it you have ruined the movie and earned a 5 on what I planned to give a 1.

reviews.review_title: Same old flaws
reviews.content: I have felt a strong repulsion against cancer movies since the term "cancer movie" came out, probably even before. It always seems that they only have the purpose to make you cry through an unrealistic depiction of terminal illness (yes, you always die of cancer in movies), gilding the pill about all the disgusting aspects of it, the ones that would tax every character's bravery and good humour, the ones that probably would make you hate more the illness itself than death. Unfortunately Me, Earl and the Dying Girl doesn't escape totally this judgment.Of course my review is globally positive: I enjoyed watching the most of it, it makes me laugh and it would probably make me cry if only I cried for this kind of movies. Nevertheless I have found in it the same flaws that all these stories always have and an additional presumption to have done something very original; but probably I should blame the book for that, not the script.The non-romantic relationship between the main character and the sick girl isn't enough to make the plot original or more realistic, and the continuous pointing it out as something different was really pretentious and annoying. Actually I didn't really like the main character either. He wasn't young enough to justify his lack of maturity and sensitiveness, and I think the movie failed in showing that there was something interesting and complex in his personality: he was invisible and anonymous even at the end of the movie, and that really made me think he had had good reasons to act that apathetic at the beginning.However probably a different ending would help. In this kind of movies it seems that you can't really escape death if you are a cancer patient, but that hasn't been true anymore for many decades. Conveying the message that cancer is always terminal, besides being utterly unrealistic, definitely won't help cancer patients and the ones who have to take care of them. Moreover letting sometimes survive the sick character wouldn't compromise the personal growth of people around them: I think that the hardest part in these situations is facing illness itself, not coping with the eventual death.

reviews.review_title: Flawed but still utterly enjoyable.
reviews.content: Yes this film does have it's flaws in particular the character 'Earl' doesn't seem real. And certain choices made (I won't say) for the mere purpose of being unpredictable. Never the less this is a film that had me chuckling in laughter and crying. What more do you want? Lovely writing, layered and even though the structure is a little cliché the message and truth behind the story is genuine. Great casting. The awkwardness is portrayed at a lovely level never forced. Olivia Cooke is outstanding in this film, she carried me with her. Not much dialogue yet she still managed to carve a hole in my heart.This isn't a normal 'High school flick' this is a film that tackles death with a sense of realistic humour.If you liked 'Perks of being a Wallflower' you will love this film.

reviews.review_title: A true masterpiece!
reviews.content: Before I get this started, this review contains spoilers so, if you have not yet seen this soon to be cult classic then read with caution. So yeah, this movie is awesome. As someone who has read the book I can confirm that this is much better than book. Not that the book wasn't also good because it was. It managed to fix all the problems I had with the book and more. So why am I praising this movie so much? There are plenty of reasons. So let's start with how perfectly cast this movie is. You don't even to read the book to see how perfect this actors are for these roles. Not only that but the performances are absolutely fantastic. They are extremely believable and convincing. They are all great but, Olivia cooks performance is easily the greatest. Just look at the scene where she is dying and she is able to convey so much emotion just using her eyes. Anybody can just scream and cry out of joy but what she was able to convey just with a gaze is amazing. This movie is very funny and also very dramatic and this film does both equally good. This movie also is beautifully scripted. Every scene makes sense and works in multiple ways. They flow right into each other. The cinematography is a very underrated thing about this movie. It's really great and very clever at times. The soundtrack is fantastic as well. All the songs perfectly match the scenes their accommodated with. Really makes you wonder why beautiful Brian Eno songs haven't been used in many other films. The fact that is masterpiece has less than an 8 on this website really ticks me off. Now that I think about it about it, there are a ton of great movies that have a less than a an 8 on this website. That is all.

reviews.review_title: A Beautiful and Emotional Film, Filled with Heart, Friendship, and Loyalty, but also Lost and discouragement
reviews.content: What can I say about this film. Me and Earl and the Dying Girl is an emotional driven film. It is also a film filled with the right blend of comedy.Me and Earl and the Dying Girl stars Thomas Mann, RJ Cyler, and Oliva Cooke. Gregg (Mann) and Earl (Cyler) are friends who make films with each other, that are parody's of classic films like Sockwork Orange. When Rachel (Cooke) suffers from Leukemia. Greg's mother, played by Connie Britton, and father, played by Nick Offerman, make him go to Rachel's house to keep her company, Greg and Rachel make a bond that includes some of the best chemistry in film. The film does a great job making you feel for the characters. Later on in the friendship, a friend known as Madison (or semi-friend, however Greg puts it in the film), wanted Greg and Earl to make a film for Rachel, and after Rachel fins out about the film from Earl (which she tells Greg she found out), they fight and Greg and Earl fight. Greg's life is turned upside down because of it. After a fight in the cafeteria, Earl helps Greg and the two, more-or-less, stop hating each other and Madison, after the three (not Madison, the guy who fought Greg) are forced to leave school grounds, Madison feels bad for pressuring Greg about the film and asks him to prom. He accepts the offer. On the day of prom, Greg has a finished film for Rachel, who is now at the final stage of her cancer (which was spoken of earlier in the film, almost directly after the scene where Rachel and Greg fight). As Greg shows her the film, she goes into the final stage of her life, and goes into a coma. Greg freaks out and bursts into tears and leaves the room. It is found out seconds later that she died after 10 hours of being in a coma. Rachel's mom, played by Molly Shannon, shows Greg a card that re-submitted him into college, which shows that it is in Pittsburgh. He, earlier, submitted a form for the university and was inducted, but was ejected because of the declining of his school work, because he was with Rachael, doing a good deed. He also finds a book that was cut with scissors to make a replica of the day when the three leads were eating ice cream on a staircase, which was also the day Greg and Earl got stoned (accidentally) got stoned/high by eating cookies. She also leaves a letter that he can have some pillows (the first day they started talking, they talked about the pillows in her room. The film ends there.The film is easily one of, if not, the best film of 2015. IT should be watched by all since it has the emotion and the heart. It is a great, great film and I recommend it to all.What do you think of it?

reviews.review_title: Trust issues, but nice movie
reviews.content: Nice movie, will make you cry. Great perspective of how precious life is, and honestly, I hope someday I'll have a friendship like Greg and Rachel. I think that Greg and Earl should've had a better friendship development.

reviews.review_title: Stand out film for 2015
reviews.content: There are not a lot of movies out there that are truly capable of making me cry, Crying is not something that I do often; nor something that I was expecting to do while watching a teen flick but OMG this movie is super emotional. I highly recommend it! Me and Earl and the Dying Girl centers around Greg (Thomas Mann; Project X), a senior who has managed to coast through high school without associating himself with any cliques or making any enemies, yet at same time keeping himself closed off from forming any true bonds. Except with, one of his teachers & his "Co-Worker" Earl. Together Greg & Earl spend their free time making parodies of weird foreign films for their amusement.When Greg's mother learns that one of his classmates has been diagnosed with cancer, she forces him to go over to her house and befriend the girl. Though he hesitates at first, what starts off as something he was forced to do, becomes the beginning of a beautiful friendship with Rachel (Olivia Cooke, Bates Motel) All the characters are superbly cast and each give one gives an absolutely solid performance. They appeared to be a really tight-knit cast, that just worked brilliantly. I especially enjoyed Nick Offerman's portrayal as Greg's dad, what an eccentric oddball of a parent; he adds a fun unique weirdness to the story. Thomas Mann is fantastic! I have enjoyed watching him in other films. I think he is someone that will have a long and successful career. He is definitely a very charismatic actor A lot of people are comparing this to "The Fault in Our Stars". I get that; but this movie is far more fresh, quirky & original. It's written so beautifully, and shows how life-changing strong friendships can be & how they can alter your outlook on life. The movie deals with a terminal illness in such a heartfelt way. It is definitely worth watching

reviews.review_title: An Epic Mosaic of the Emotions, both the Painful and the Good
reviews.content: No Spoilers, Please enjoy.I always wondered what it would like to see a masterpiece where others did not. As I was sitting in the theater at the close of this film I saw a few groups of teenagers who had bought the ticket and taken the ride looking confused, bored, and eager to return to their smartphones. And so with that, I, with a heavy heart, do not recommend this film to everyone and that just makes be bitter to be an American. Now, the film itself is really two films in one. The first a comedy. The second, I don't know what but call it something magnificent and full of real blood pumping from a real heart and made me take a real minute to sort out how I was living my life. I almost died once, in a hospital. I was at the time scared and lonely and mean. This movie rehashed that experience for me in a way that can only be described as through a lens of emotional maturation, if you can follow me. I am now stronger in the broken places, as Hemingway would say. It is because of brave filmmakers who brave the bullshiting critics and the greedy consumers and blast away all the superficial scum that piles up on us all in this all-too-fast all- to-now all-to-much place we wander through between the partnered miracles of life and death. The main character, Greg, began the film as a smooth talking, hilarious and universally accepting kid, wonderfully unbelievable but entertainingly played by Thomas Mann who makes his way through the plot of this sharp film by being a kid who has to grow up quick when facing truly adult emotions like regret and sacrifice and ending up... well, ending up... It is always an on-going process, this ending thing we do, isn't it? His life wasn't finished at the end of the film so I hope for him, like any real person outside of cinema to keep living and keep growing, smiling whenever possible, crying when necessary, never losing a lesson learned.The black guys in this film were almost psychically reading the repressed thoughts of the white people around them. Very refreshing.Greg's categorization of everyone in his high school into sub-groups was a very egalitarian way of think of the social order of any social hodge podge. Every group complete separate from one another but equal. (I worry that's what Southern whites said about segregation but I'll apologize and move on). Much improved over the very old and very elitist socio-economic structuring that most high schoolers nowadays do semi-consciouslly as their parents did before them and their parents before them.The directing... impeccable. The screenplay... superb. The acting... touching and genuine. (Those last remarks were a joke. If you don't get it I wish I could explain it.)I titled this review "An Epic Mosaic of the Emotions, both the Painful and the Good" because whenever i watch The Wolf of Wall Street, a favorite, I always feel I have to watch another film to balance out all the riotous pleasure with some pain. Pain is good and there are few better environments to experience it than a movie theater. This film was massive in the range of emotions yet balanced, making me feel that this was maybe the most complete film I have ever seen if you'll agree with me in my criteria for completeness being based upon the "number" of emotions a film can authentically and sincerely hit upon without running four hours. I was once handed a list of emotions on paper by someone who wanted to help, more than a hundred listed, but they were just words and so is this review... So see the film, I can't recommend to to anyone who reads this whole review more highly.Darn, darn, darn the movie was over and I had learned something from it. I learned that death is not the end of somebodies life, that you don't have to talk like a genius to have the heart of a poet, that Molly Shannon can really, really act, that it's never too late to start loving someone and its childish to hold a grudge, that things don't necessarily have to ever get better but you're always free to let the sunshine pour in, that a theater is a dark place full of bright things, that love does not make sense and will never do so, that we are all not created equal because some of us sit in theaters and stare at the pretty colors while others are out there in the world making Me, Earl, and the Dying Girl. Thank you to everyone listed on the film's end credits. If it takes a village to raise a child, it takes a city to make a movie.Thanks for reading. Email me if you like at jemery1889@gmail.com Sometimes a little encouragement is all the caterpillar needs. I'm twenty.

reviews.review_title: Unlike those of its kind
reviews.content: The best way to summarize this movie would be to state that it is unlike any regular high school movie with grown up themes. It is a movie that in all of its simplicity conveys no real message of love, hope or strength in any way but manages to do this in a spectacular way. It has no happy or sad ending as the plot has no real basis for a climax but it is nonetheless joyous to watch. It has the possibility of bringing tears to your eyes when immersed in it. With all of these qualities, I believe that this movie is one to be seen by teenagers who are approximately as old as the characters and who may be able to relate to the characters. Watching it will be time well spent and it will trigger your emotional side. I would definitely recommend it.

reviews.review_title: Words Won't Do The Justice
reviews.content: It's been years since I cried the last time. Be it any reason, watching movies, listening to Kurt Cobain, or Chester Bennington (yeah, before he passed, his music still touched hearts), or getting my ass whooped by my dad.But this movie, it changes things. It changes how you feel about a person who's slowly passing away. Each moment of their life is a pain knowing that it's never coming back and probably before anything even comes close would be too late. The decisions one's gotta make, irrespective whether you've been in the life of the person before the news spread or not. The people, of whom you'd think that they're just plain selfish, but they're not. Tonnes of other stuff that I can't go on about..The clock of crying got reset today. 0 days and counting.

reviews.review_title: The most beautiful thing about this movie is that it's not a sock puppet
reviews.content: This movie is a great adaptation but it needed a bit more from the novel, I'm not saying it should have been the exact same just a little bit more than what we haveNeeds more excessive modesty and more darth vader/pirates saying they like leukemiaOther than that i feel like the prom thing was a bit unnecessary, and they took out the part where greg's mother shows the movie to the entire school and they all hated it, and alot of great things that the book had. So in conclusion, go read the book it's just like the movie but better

reviews.review_title: A beautifully shot; anti- YA movie
reviews.content: Don't get me wrong making books into movies has always been around but during about 2009 to 2017 the young adult genre was essentially taken for granted, with books being made into cash grab movies. Which is what makes this movie so special. It takes all the introspective bs and touchy feely stuff that is over romanticized in YA movies and turns it on its head. It's the perfect anti-YA.

reviews.review_title: Excellent: NOT sad or sappy
reviews.content: Very uniquely well done coming of age story.First off, it is NOT a sad depressing movie. That was what I was afraid of when I went to see this. Second, it is NOT sappy and melodramatic. It has a great vibe to it. Very gritty and real feeling, complete with the awkwardness and defense mechanisms every teenager is full of. It has a lot of great quirky humor. The main characters are nicely developed and you really feel like you know them and care for them by the end. The dying girl thing is a nice way to make the story unique from your typical coming of age story and it is handled superbly. Must see movie.

reviews.review_title: All the feels!
reviews.content: This film is so good in my opinion for it's ability to make you feel multiple emotions in such a short period of time. It goes from laughing to tearing up to a genuine interest in what's happening very fast and this is done with great writing and cinematography.The film follows a similar structure to some of my other favourite films however at the centre of it is a simple story arc paired with a smart/intellectual script. The thing that caught me off guard with this was the misdirection of it making you think the cheesy/predictable thing would happen but then surprises you.The only negative I can think of is that it can feel slow and depressing at times but with a film about cancer what do you expect. This film is definitely worth the watch If you like the indie film, coming of age, crying alone at 2am kind of vibe you might be getting from the trailer.

reviews.review_title: About "Me and Earl and the Dying Girl".
reviews.content: Alfonso Gomez-Rejon's POV is both fresh and wonderful. He manages to approach an obscure subject such as death in a very humane and warm way, among other characters like how tough it actually is to grow up, and how really complicated human interaction is. The movie keeps you interested, it moves you and touches some very delicate fibers in the way. It has a smart script, with understandable dialogue and relatable characters that, thank God, have more than one dimension. I find the acting to be superb, specially the acting performed by Thomas Mann, R.J. Cyler and Olivia Cooke, the young actors that play the principal characters of the film. They will make you laugh and cry. It also made me very happy that there's no unnecessary drama, just very human reactions to very human problems. I feel it has some sort of Little-Miss-Sunshine/Juno feel to it, feeling just so intimate and natural, giving it some realness that most of us are craving for. Getting a bit techy, I must say I find the film's cinematography to be very simple and pretty. It has a Wes-Anderson-y feel to it, still being very down-to-Earth. On top of that, it has amazing music that goes with it; mellow and soft, but never corny. It also has very decent editing. All in all, I very much recommend it. Just a warning; keep a box of tissues around.

reviews.review_title: a beautiful film
reviews.content: Greg (Thomas Mann) is a fairly typical high school boy with passion for old movies and the creation of new ones, and like many film makers, he prefers to observe people instead of growing attached to them. His best friend is Earl (wonderfully played by RJ Cyler) whom he describes as "more like a coworker than a friend" and otherwise he isolates himself and creates new films he never shows anyone. At his mother's insistence, he begins visiting Rachel (Olivia Cook) who has been diagnosed with leukemia. Though initially reluctant, Greg begins to genuinely look forward to hanging out with her, which challenges his desire to remain a neutral force in other people's lives. The first ten minutes of the film are stiff and awkward and trapped in teen movie hell, but it's supposed to be that way, so hang in there. The strange beauty of the film comes from the authenticity of the characters, and the brilliant portrayal of the complexities of terminal illness. In most movies you're forced to endure a sick person who essentially becomes Yoda for everyone in their lives, offering wisdom and guidance and poetry and a few well-timed coughs before they sputter away to the sobs and wails of everyone around them. This movie shows what cancer truly is: miserable, with a lot of people offering ridiculous canned sentiment over and over again, who only want to make themselves feel better about what they're witnessing. It also brilliant captures what people miss about others when they remain guarded and unobservant of what lies beyond surface examination -- or remain too preoccupied of what others think of them to realize that other people are thinking about a whole lot of different things -- not them. It manages to do this without being so heavy-handed about it that a hallmark sentiment hatches on your face, and your eyes roll out of your head to escape it. Jesse Andrews pulled off a gorgeous book and screenplay, and Alfonso Gomez-Rejon also deserves props for graceful direction and imagination. Every character is given room to be unique and fully-formed, and retains their humanity to the very end. I was very reluctant to watch this film, out of fear of watching a cancer spectacle similar to the overwrought emotional farming that has taken place a lot over the past ten years, but this is a different film all together. Take a chance on it; it's worth it. I'll be watching each of these actors and Alfonso Gomez-Rejon closely to see what they accomplish next.

reviews.review_title: It has the classic indie vibe that you expect
reviews.content: If you watched the trailer for this movie, you will probably expect the classic indie drama with romantic spice on the top of it. Well, yes this is that kind of movie. You will find the typical stereotypes in every young-adult movie; The awkward protagonist with a somewhat comical relieve best friend and of course the girl which the whole story resolves throughout the movie. Even though the concept seems predictable and recycled, it doesn't make it not enjoyable. The directing and editing of this movie are some work of art, the pacing flows smoothly every bits of the frame is really enjoyable. It has great soundtrack despite they aren't used often and the timing is perfect. The acting is relatively great despite some minor characters. In the end, this is not a flick for you to watch if you are expecting some Oscar level piece or some life transcending movie experience. But if you want to just chill and feel some good vibe to waste your time alone or with some friends (I prefer alone) This one will definitely be a classic.

reviews.review_title: Sydney Film Festival
reviews.content: saw this at Sydney film festival, absolutely great!! don't know why some of you guys are voting against the film but personally, i thought it was great, will watch it again when releases in cinemas in September down here in Australia. The place i watched it in was packed to it's maxed considering the demand on this movie, and was that really wolverine's voice or an interpretation.? I have seen many movies this year and by far this is one of the best combinations of comedy and drama into one movie. Just thought that should of shown more scenes with olivia cooke in it. The movie itself put out a fake spoiler at the start and only reviewed its true ending towards the end where those of you that watched it will know, they also put a funny joke at the end which ended the movie quite nicely in my opinion. with all the sadness to be able to end it with a bit of comedy absolutely bought it for me.

reviews.review_title: SOOOO much better than the book!
reviews.content: I'd seen this film and recognized it immediately as one of the books I'd been meaning to read for a while. Therefore, I knew I HAD to watch it. There's something so stunningly simply and simply stunning about this film that I can't put my finger on, just little details that have me laughing and crying, and sometimes- both at once! I think the main thing that captured me about this was the truthfulness to it. This film manages to portray the ugliness regarding terminal illness that some gloss over in a way that is light and fun but still serious enough to convey the tragedy of what is a reality for millions of people all over the world. There is so much truth in this film that it threatens to make the viewer explode. I was overcome with emotion and how very ordinary and extraordinary these characters were. The main three actors/actress were absolutely amazing! I especially loved the real awkwardness and nerdiness that comes with real-life teenagers (something that is often missed out to create ideal people). This film deals with so many things all at once, but it is never too overwhelming that you are left unable to process it- it's utterly perfect. It might take a while for you to get into it, unless you are wonderfully wacky! Greg is a weirdo. It's as simple as that. His humor is subjective and he tends to say the wrong things (like we all do at times). However, he is still lovable and caring and deeply invested in his friends. All I can say is if you liked this film, DON'T READ THE BOOK! I was bitterly disappointed with the book, especially as my expectations had been set high from the film. I finished it, but it dragged, despite the few scenes of brilliance. In the book, the characters are unfeeling and it is very difficult to care for them. In the film, you fall in love with them all for so many different reasons. Just watch it. It's beautiful.

reviews.review_title: How a Book to Movie Remake Should Be
reviews.content: In this era of every movie being based on a book, Me and Earl and The Dying Girl proves that maybe the movie can be better than the book. Jesse Andrews, the author of the book, sets up the story perfectly for a film adaptation, to the point where it almost seems as if this was his true intent with the story. This film is beautiful, it plays with stop motion, shaped frames, camera angles and drawing in a way that no other film has done in recent years. The handmade aesthetic of the film is perfect for the main character Greg as his mind sees the world through film. This is a movie for everyone, film fanatics will appreciate the many references and homages to past films and people looking for a teen, cancer romance will find this is the perfect story, feel good and heart breaking. This film is often compared to The Fault in Our Stars, for a good reason, the stories are very similar, however Me and Earl seems to be what TFIOS could have been. This film stands alone, an audience doesn't need to read the book to understand and fall in love/hate with the characters. The acting and direction is stunning, with the three leading teens stealing the show. This is truly a spectacle of what teen flicks could be if we don't settle for the mediocre films being produced today.

reviews.review_title: Missing a lot from the book
reviews.content: The movie diden´t have some part of the book that made the book so great to read. The movie was missing some important detals like Greg having siblings or the ending like the book had but not the movie which I thoguh was important. But I still liked the movie very much despised that the movie made me cry so plus point for that.

reviews.review_title: from a few different perspectives
reviews.content: This is a film that is easily appreciated. To use a very uncommon phase, I do beileve that the film was better than the book. This is in no disregared to the author himself. I really did enjoy the text. In fact, its rare for me to be writting about a film in which I read the book first. I am movie of a movie person, always have been. I don't really feel like you would be writing on here (or reading for that matter) if you weren't. But what do I know.For what I would give about 90%, the film was accurate to the text. And I give my applause to them, because while the book was funny and well timed, it can be hard to recite tine from a book in a film without it feeling incredibly cheesy. Many things just sound better in your head- its a fact. But Thomas Mann had the perfect amount of whit and sarcasm to pull it off. As someone who many have just watched the film, I was convinced that this was the perfect person to comfort a dying girl. Well done.What put the film over the edge of the book would be the ending. Having Rachel die while watching the film, then more or less cutting to the visitation at her house was so beautiful in comparison to the crude ending of the novel where the film os showed to the entire school and Greg and Earl are left feeling completely rejected. I suppose the books can get away with this type of reality in there work, as they are much more complicated and have many more aspects in which to appreciate and notice. This movie was shooting for a good time- as all are, and needed a more sweet ending. They nailed it. Although there is a heart gripping moment that Greg has with his mom that I wished I could have seen, I understand how that may clash with the overall tone of the film. It is, after all, the most lighthearted take of one of most heavy situations. For this instance, I enjoyed what I watched more so than what I read, and that is the truth.I rally hated writing that because I find those comparisons rather annoying, but I also felt like it was worth being said. As an appreciation of the film itself, the style of editing was a great reflection of the style in which Greg and Earl made films themselves. Completely genius. Also stunned on how the soundtrack could seem so fitting for the theme without being overly powerful or overly know. Many film of this sort do try to use smaller artist and many times just miss the mark. Or they may just a song too well know, it which I call them a try hard.I do recommend this film. It timeless in the most casual of ways.

reviews.review_title: Watch this to the very end. (minor spoiler)
reviews.content: I'm 61 years old, but this movie about teenagers captures my heart. I don't wanna say too much, except perhaps that the writing shines and the acting lives up to the writing and so much more. Watch this movie to the very end. Also the music is quirky and haunting. Every actor does a great job, up to and including the clichéd "hot girl." I like how his mother prevails against the hero's teenage angst. She just rolls over him with relentless, grown up logic. Every character is like a portrait of a real person. You get it that the author knew those people. They come to life in all their quirky, humanity, not clichés here, just brilliant pictures of real human beings. Loved this movie. Loved it.

reviews.review_title: Fantastic Film. Guaranteed to release your emotional side!
reviews.content: I'm not one for writing reviews normally but after watching this film I had a sudden urge to share my thoughts with others. Certainly wouldn't be the kind of film I would normally choose to watch, I would consider my self a man's man only ever looking for the action packed thrillers or gore fest of a good horror. However, on this occasion it was taken completely out of my hands due to Odeon Screen Unseen. First time I've been to a screen unseen and I can honestly say when the name of the film came up as we were sat in the cinema I was disappointed that it wasn't one of the bigger upcoming films such as Legend or Black Mass. Nonetheless, I'd already agreed with my Girlfriend that no matter what it turned out to be we would both stick through it and I'm so glad we did. Its an unusual film that never gets boring and whilst it can be quite depressing in parts it also has some very awkward sections leading to some brilliantly comical moments. I thought the casting was great with some unexpected Actors filling the supporting roles perfectly, namely; John Bernthal, Nick Offerman and Connie Britton.The way the film takes you through such a set of emotions from happy and joyous to sad, frustrated and angry is fantastic and has truly opened my eyes to a different genre of film I would never have thought to visit beforehand.Finally I'll say a big thumbs up to Odeon for their Screen Unseen and can only hope the next invite brings as good a film with it.

reviews.review_title: Overdramatic teenager goes through a tough time
reviews.content: What do you do when a friend is dying? We focus on that terrifying moment and forget about everything that's going on around us. In a way, that's the central theme of this movie. How can we remain empathetic when we're suffering too? Having a teenager go through this is a great choice. Especially one that's weird, dramatic and awkward. It helped make moments that would make you cringe feel meh. A few of those moments missed the mark, but the rest were pretty effective. I enjoyed this movie because it felt real, and even though it can tough at times it's definitely worth your time.

reviews.review_title: Most Beautiful Movie I've Ever Seen, Not to Mention Hilarious
reviews.content: It's rare that I give a movie a 10 out of 10. Yet, I had good reason. This movie was hands down the most beautifully developed and heart-wrenchingly performed movie I've ever seen. It really made me realize that there are still good people, and people who appreciate good people, out there. Though it's a movie, movies like this can only be based on real life experiences that really rip your heart apart. Greg is so quirky and awkward, but in a rare and hilarious way, and Earl just adds to the hilarity. His pure genuineness, kindness, and 'over-the-top humility,' as Rachel put it, come packaged in that awkward casing; deep down you knew those former qualities were always there, but they truly emerge and blossom as you see him give of himself to Rachel day in and day out. He almost sacrificed his senior year and future for her. That is true friendship and love at its finest.Though Greg started spiraling (understandably) when he found out Rachel was stopping treatment, he showed his true colors when he brought the corsage to the hospital to give to his date. My heart was very satisfied when I heard that ambulance as he got out of the limo. He proved to be a real gentleman and good person, which are rare commodities nowadays. I think the beauty of the movie truly hit me at the end of the movie when they revealed quirky and artistic things about Rachel even after her death. (On a side note, I knew that I couldn't believe Greg when he said she wouldn't die That was the only thing he said in that movie that didn't sound genuine.) As Greg walked through the room, perusing her shelves of concave book art, and as I watched him trace the squirrel's path from wall tree to wall tree, hearing him describe the story behind her ashes being thrown in the park behind her house, I couldn't help but fall in love with her character and the movie as a whole. The ending was frustrating and painful and deeply heart-wrenching, but piercingly beautiful. I would watch this 1,000 times more. I don't know if I even want to watch another movie like it because I'll always have this profound, magnificent.movie to compare it to. I am deeply wonderfully satisfied.

reviews.review_title: Ease the pain, then bring it back: Awesome
reviews.content:
This film is truly original. I can not stop thinking about it. Everything it shows you is necessary from beginning to end. The narator tells the watcher she doesn't die in the end, and that takes the attention away from the girl and it brings a real "coming of age" vibe to the story. This is supported by the great way it shows how you can feel when someone you like touches you and more. 
But then, in the end, she dies anyway. Even though everyone suspected this, it is still a great plot twist and it brings back the pain of losing. This makes the end the pinnacle of the movie, and end this fenomenal scenario. Thank you to everyone credited.

reviews.review_title: Simply Amazing! A must watch!
reviews.content: People may think a 10 is high. And it is. A 10 is a very high score. But to me personally this deserves it. I have seen it matched up against, they are two very different films I'm just about every aspect but the cancer pretty much. I saw TFiOS first a while ago. I thought it was a great movie. I still agree it is good movie. I would happily watch it again. Today i saw this on IMDb and decided to watch it. WOW. I am so happy i did. I am not ashamed to say i cried like a baby 2 or 3 times. No movie has done that before. It is a very artsy film and it is done perfectly. It fits very well! The build up is long some people may say "Slow" but it is very much needed. The film would have had no where near as much of an impact without that. The acting was on point. I have seen Olivia Cooke's work before in Bates Motel and she was amazing. This film has made me love her more! This was the first time i have heard of Thomas Mann but woah! Where has he been hiding and why has he had so few jobs! I see he has quite a few coming up and i am 100% going to watch every one of them because his acting was superb! If you are still reading then what the hell are you doing? GO WATCH THE FILM ALREADY!

reviews.review_title: Delightfully grounding
reviews.content: If Wes Anderson had written and directed his high-school years - only with slightly more clichés than he'd be comfortable with - I'd like to imagine that 'Me and Earl and the Dying Girl' would be the final product. The character of Greg embodies a delightfully grounding balance of cynicism, pragmatism and child-like imagination that ultimately produces an immensely satisfying and perplexing lens through which to view the world.

reviews.review_title: nice and sad
reviews.content: While i watching this movie i thought that is the nicest film i have ever seen , But at the end it turn out this is the most saddest realistic movie i have ever seen . it's weird that i didn't feel the time while watching it , it doesn't have so much story but it is so enjoyable and interesting .it's like watching 90 movies . And by the way i think this movie capture high school in a good way also teenager. I think that sometime we need to watch movies like this movies that said " miracle don't happen and life goes on ".Anddddd the movie is NOT like the fault in our star which is a good movie too .

reviews.review_title: A quirky, but sad teenage drama.
reviews.content: I read the book before the movie, and I thought it was really great. However I was a bit skeptical of a movie adaption, because while the book was great, it didn't seem like it would make an entertaining movie unless you completely discard the overall message. Thankfully, this is not the case. This movie isn't the perfect adaption, but it is pretty damn good. You're going to run into a few corny scenes here and there especially during the climax (at least in my opinion) but it didn't ruin my overall experience. The movie is perfectly cast, and stays true to the book while still being a very entertaining movie in its own right. You should go into this movie expecting a quirky but somewhat realistic depiction of youth, and if that sounds interesting to you I don't think you'll be unhappy.

reviews.review_title: Utterly brilliant
reviews.content: For me a good movie is one where you sit in the cinema and become simply absorbed in the whole film. You are not thinking 'that's good acting ' of how brilliant the cinematography is you simply become part of the film. This is one of those films This film is just brilliant. It's a love story but it's not in the 'note book ' genre. To me it's about how two people who have lost their way for different reasons can fall completely in love with the other person and in doing so find their own way and grow. It so lulls you into believing there is going to be a truly happy ending and then just punches you in the gut but then somehow squeezes an uplifting hope at the end The actors are great but Olivia Cooke gives an utterly brilliant performance as a young girl trying to come to terms with a terminal illness with a fragility that just draws you into her fears and somewhat acceptance of what faces her I laughed. I cried I was devistated. But I walked out of the cinema and loved every second with a smile

reviews.review_title: Get you laugh, get you cry
reviews.content: I loved the conversations in this movie, and how the characters expressed their feelings. I loved the movie doesn't have any dramatic turn up or turn down, things just happened. It brings up my smile and tears, gonna put it on my fav list.

reviews.review_title: By far my favorite movie
reviews.content: This movie presented the perfect balance of comedy and sadness. It is not your classic romantic comedy but a friendship that changed a few lives for the better.

reviews.review_title: Beautiful movie on a topic you might think is overused in cinema
reviews.content: Yeah, that was what I initially thought when considering going to the movie. It is a topic that makes it to the big screen far too often. Heck, we even had "the Fault in our Stars" so, so recently.Thankfully, I did decide to go and see it. Must have been something in the poster. It did look different. And so did the movie. First, it was really shot masterfully. I have never imagined that a typical high-school could be seen from such angles. The way we are presented with the home of the "Dying Girl" actually reflects the way the protagonist sees it. At some point of the movie, it turns out he has missed so much. And we had, too, because the director and cinematographer had done such a great job.The plot was really well played out. You are constantly forced into the skin of the protagonist to the point where you take everything he says for granted and you do feel what he's feeling. And he is both a typical and a very different kid. He's both mature (especially in areas such as cynicism and in taking care to look calmer than he actually is) and really, really immature (in issues relating to girls, of course, parents, his future, etc.)A note: the film is not about poking fun at anyone's suffering. It does touch on the topic of accepting things with a smile and moving on, but without forgetting. My only actual criticism of the movie relates to the very ending, hence this SPOILER ALERT! I really loved the scene where Greg explored Rachel's room and saw what he had missed to see so many times before. Th squirrels, the scissors, the things she did with the books. It was beautiful and really emotional. That is when he must have finally come to understood his wacky teacher's words about how you continue to learn things from and about the people you've lost even after they are already gone. It is a great message, but why did he have to spell it out in the next scene? We perfectly got it from the scene in Rachel's room and having it spelled out just about ruined the effect of that particular scene. I understand that the target audience might not understand it otherwise, but subtlety is the best approach to movie endings.Nevertheless, the movie was beyond great. I've marked the cinematographer and the director and hope to see their next projects soon.

reviews.review_title: A movie that can make a man shed a tear
reviews.content: The Story so beautifully written and executed. Characters played their parts ever so naturally. The attention to detail, the cinematography, the back ground music , the subtle reactions at the right time, each character molded to perfection. Do not miss the ending where all that the main characters talk about falls into place. Felt real good to watch that. The suspense of it all, I was infatuated with all the camera the main character has and how he and the dying girl was brought together and how their take of all the classics. The director has done his job perfectly. made this movie one of the best I've seen for quite sometime. so with no expectations, let not the movie title worry you, or the title of this ramble. Watch and you will love it.

reviews.review_title: Wow! Magical gem. Had no preconceptions but it had me laughing hysterically and left me in tears
reviews.content: I'm only here because I need to show my appreciation of this absolute gem. I'm a vigorous fan of teen/adolescence/coming-of-age movies and this one completely blew me away. With a mix of a quirky indie feel, of having me cry out with laughter even though I was alone because of subtle well-timed awful jokes, and of its unforced and undramatic way of inducing sadness it managed to entertain and enthral from beginning to end. The main characters are fun and credible albeit the exaggerated minor characters such as the badass history teacher, alcoholic mom, social science professor dad, and all of the classic high-school stereotypes. Part of what I enjoyed the most was the little bits of movies that Greg and Earl had made, which are both visually engaging and provides something of a commentary to the actual movie progression. Couldn't give 'Me Earl and the Dying Girl' a warmer recommendation! Enjoy!

reviews.review_title: Heartwarming Story, great script, good acting, nice movie.
reviews.content: I've seen this movie about a week ago and I still think about it. When I heard about the movie I thought of a typical teenager lover story, but it's not at all a teenager love story. This is a film about growing up and friendship and even though I'm not a teenager anymore I feel like the movie taught me a lot about how to handle friends who have serious health problems.I love how the characters evolve nicely throughout the movie, how unique every one of them is. I think that the writer did a great job on creating the characters which might not be believable all the time, but are charming and fun to watch.So if you expect a teenager lover story, don't, it's not a love story and if you like good cinematography, good characters, good dialogs and fluid story telling, watch the movie, you won't regret it

reviews.review_title: Sugar coated bitter truth of life
reviews.content: P.S: May contain spoilersThe fact that nothing is permanent in this world is depicted in the most elegant way in this movie. Comparing this movie to 'The Fault in Our Stars' would be shear foolishness. Even though there is death involved in both the movies, each of them has a different way of presenting it to the audience. All the aspects of life including life, death, love, friendship and other relationships could be clearly seen here. The part that pierced my heart was where Rachel, even during her last days, did her best to fix Greg's life. One has a lot to learn from this film and I would highly recommend it to someone who has lost faith on movies and life as well.

reviews.review_title: Give it a go!
reviews.content: I watched the movie with some specific expectations, but to be honest: the movie did quite well and exceeded them."Me and Earl and the Dying Girl" handles an sensitive core topic very decently with a authentic and entertaining narrative. Alfonso Gomez-Rejon has done a great job by conveying the very essence of every scene/moment precisely to the audience. Astonished by the smooth directing and cinematography, the movie kept me interested it till the end. The story itself is quite simple and is shaped by realistic characters, however it handles a serious topic, which makes it worth it to watch. The cast did well, whereas the Thomas Mann and Olivia Cooke seems to have a promising career ahead of them. I personally would recommend this movie and think that is the best work by Gomez-Rejon so far.

reviews.review_title: A film that touched my heart!
reviews.content: This is a production unlike most today. The writhing and the emotions that visibly went into the it are visible. As a famous film-maker once said "Story is king, everything else is there to highlight it.". I would strongly recommend this film for people who have lost someone fighting cancer, the warmth of nostalgia you feel after watching it is going to stay with you for a long time and remind what is really important in life!Acting was superb, Thomas Mann did a marvellous job of making the diverse plot seem realistic and making the viewer feel part of the story.Thanks to the whole crew for making a real, pure and emotional production unlike anything I have seen in the last couple of years.

reviews.review_title: 5 Reasons why I liked "Me and Earl and The Dying Girl"
reviews.content: Me And Earl And The Dying Girl , is a movie based on a novel with the same name by Jesse Andrews and directed by Alfonso Gomez-Rejon and the actors are Thomas Mann(Greg , or the main guy) , RJ Cyler as Earl and Olivia Cooke as Rachel (or the dying girl) , the main plot is about a guy who is generally awkward , not belonging to any groups or gangs , self hating and abnormally separated(well at least it's not abnormal in my perspective ) , Greg has only one thing in his life , pass time and make lame movies with earl who he refuses to call a friend , and one day all of a sudden his mom tells him that Rachels mom called and said she is diagnosed with cancer, Greg early that day heard Rachel with her friends talking about a test and he thinking it's a school test tries to be funny which as usual is not, so Greg who has no idea why he gets involved in this story is forced by both his mom and his guilt for throwing words without actually knowing the story behind it has to hangout , he actually forces Rachel to hangout with him cause he knows his mom will always remind him of her and therefore he will remember his lame joke about the test , so with time Rachel gets worse and worse and Greg later does the hanging out kind of not because the previous reasons anymore but more because he gets in a kind of emotion with her , another side of the story is that hot girl in school who Greg thinks she is trying to use her hotness to make him do things she wants, not understanding she does all that so that she make Greg notice her .now I'm being like Greg talking too much awkwardly without saying the main thing which is :5 Reasons why I liked the movie so bad ,1-the movie showed how Greg pretended to like the separate life and somehow everyone thought he actually does which he doesn't , he tries so hard to be a funny and liked guy but who cares? and in the end giving up was all what is left to him , so he wants to give up until Rachel happen which actually makes him see how he is not a useless human if he tries even though he fails in the starting but later people start to communicate2- cancer , yes cancer stories are always touching , imagine if 50/50 was about ALS instead of cancer , wouldn't have been that touching , but no in this one you get another side of cancer , cancer more likely from the perspective of the close people of the victim , neither from the one with cancer nor from the people who are far enough not to care , it doesn't tell you how she was feeling it only shows it to you through the story . 3-she, simply giving up.. well no she doesn't simply give up she does take treatment in the first place but yeah when it doesn't work she does give up , that makes you understand what it must be like to see the way ahead
